Absolutely phenomenal! A true masterpiece! I experienced this film exactly as it was meant to be seen-on an IMAX screen where it truly shines! Anyone who spread the word that this is a musical should reconsider ever speaking again. The movie is intense and unfiltered, offering a deep insight into the Joker's psychosis. It portrays him as a relatable individual, allowing us to see a part of ourselves in him. This film highlights the way we treat certain marginalized groups in society and the consequences of that treatment. The relentless victimization, even from those who claim to care or offer support, is profoundly impactful.

I won't spoil the ending, but let me just say-it's incredible! The entire film is simply amazing!

Joker 1 was a refreshingly new take on Joker. Instead of turning him into a cartoon villain, no pun intended, it instead portrayed him as a deeply disturbed individual who was given a very raw deal in life and how that put him into a spiral of violence and madness. This movie had an excellent opportunity to continue this progression and turn him into the diabolical Batman arch-enemy we all know he should be.

But instead they made the asinine choice to turn it into a ehr... musical? For me such a choice could be only for one reason and that is to revert the expectations of the original fans and turn this movie into a joke, again no pun intended. Also, ignoring the boring musical parts, the movie just feels pointless. Half of the movie in an insane asylum and the other part in courtroom. Going back and forth trying to explain what he did in the first movie. But for what? We already saw the first movie and many felt it put Arthur Fleck into the path where he transcends his mortal form and become the immortal Joker. But this movie takes a u-turn and turns him back into Arthur Fleck and then ends his path in a brutal fashion.

This is a terrible movie which seems to hate its prequel and want to undo it. So I recommend skipping this movie entirely and just re-watch Joker 1 and use your imagination on how he transformed into Joker. Whatever you imagine it will be better than this trash of a movie.

This issue affects all movies since 01/01/2020, and especially The Joker 2. Underlit. Deliberately poor lighting. Not dark! It doesn't feel dark. It would feel dark, if it's logic was BRUTAL. Like in all movies of this decade, the logic is STUPID. Not brutal. Not dark. As a result of the stupid logic, the movie needs to be underlit. It covers up the smell of stupid logic. A stupid movie doesn't feel as stupid, if you turn down the light. To repeat the distinction, 'dark' and 'underlit' are two different things. All recent movies (with no exception) have plots sooo stupid, that you can't turn the light on. The stupidity would show. Compare this with the opening sequence of Star Wars 4 (1978). It shows the corridor of a Battle Cruiser space ship. That corridor is ALL white. As bright as bright can get. And yet it feels dark. Because the logic is so dark. The empire is about to capture a gigantic space ship by force, and they are succeeding. Dark! Despite the squeaky white corridor. All recent movies conversely are underlit. Stupid. Don't watch it. If the trailer is dark by means of insufficient lithing then no need to watch that movie. It can only be a stupid movie like The Joker 2. Or look at the production date. Later than 01/01/2020 = underlit = stupid.

After having seen this movie yesterday I can't believe how a movie as great as the joker could've gotten such a senseless sequel. The only positive aspect is Phoenix' acting ability. Lady Gaga's character is an empty shell without any character depth, development, or good acting.

The most annoying part is that just because there's Lady Gaga in it the main characters now have to sing forgettable musical numbers every few minutes. When she started singing yet again I could see people in the cinema rolling their eyes.

Above all, this movie does not really have an entertaining story and manages to convey almost nothing of interest in it's long runtime. I think it's an insult to the first movie and all DC and Joker fans to give us such an unneeded sequel that dies not add anything new to the first.

One of Joker 2 Quotes to summarize it perfectly: Stop always singing to me and talk to me.

The reason I am giving 10 stars is the fact that everyone here is rating the film based on their expectations. People went into this film expecting a film similar to the first Joker, and were disappointed. And, of course, the sequel is obviously not as good as the first, but it is NOT a 5/10 movie.

Joker: Folie à Deux is about Arthur's perception of the Joker. The musical bits were an authorial choice to convey his current mental states to the audience, and it worked. Yes, the movie is a bit slow, and there isn't much of a storyline, but I still was able to enjoy the film since it wasn't about a "story," it was supposed to be about Arthur and the Joker himself.

Thankfully, I went into the theater with zero expectations, as should everyone that watches it. It is something "new" and enjoyable if you have correctly directed expectations.

My real rating would be 7/10 - acting was phenomenal, as in the first movie, and even though there was minimal storyline, it was still enjoyable to see Arthur's character development.

They've destroyed some very promising sequel that could've been , with a musical. Alienated the original audience that lauded the joker for it's intricacies and character development.

Lady Gaga is a singer, very good one but imo she is no where close to playing Harley Quinn. Who was she? Why is this movie titled Joker? Where is the insanity or character progress?

Joaquin is a great actor, but even his skills can't save a script written so poorly that ppl were yawning in the theater and probably waiting for the movie to get better, the better part never came and the hope eventually died.

This is a mess of ideas that doesn't fulfill the promise of the title. Watch at your own risk.

Lady Gaga claimed that Joker: Folie à Deux, wasn't a musical in the way that most other musicals use music. Repeatedly bursting into song constitutes a musical for me love! It crudely tried to frame the film within that surreal experience of watching song and dance. I can't abide musicals! The crossover into the medium of overly expressive music is lame. Arkham inmates might as well have been given a spoonful of sugar to help their medicine go down! However, this really doesn't work as a savy cinematography trick that's convincing of psychosis either-more like a meloncholy Gotham crossed with Grease. It's just not the one that I want. Arthur Fleck is a pitiful Joker. This killer is given that tiresome 'victim' angle from which he never transcends into the legendary supervillain. The only tie to the traditional DC Joker is face paint and a goofy laugh. It's a long, drawn out, boring, pointless sequel that leads nowhere.

Joker Part 2 is a visual representation of what it means to never meet your heroes.

Joker: Folie à Deux is more of a straight up drama that is still intense and delivers on the emotional aspect and stay rent free in peoples minds.

This movie is Excellent. It was a great experience watching it. I cant think of a better way to continue the Joker Story. If you think this movie is a Musical, you CLEARLY didn't understood the movie. You are in the head of Arthur, thats way he danced so much in the first one, now you are seeing it with him.

This movie is for people with higher IQs, not for single minded that wanted to see Joker suddenly skilled like John Wick and evil / strategic like a Marvel villain.

We got an A+ sequel.

Just came out of the local first night showing of the new Joker film - Joker: Folie à deux. What a film, an acting masterclass again from Joaquin Phoenix with brilliant support from Lady Gaga. No spoilers here, just get to watch it before you know too much about it and don't be put off by the negative reviews on here. This is obviously my opinion but it matches my daughter and son in law who watched it with me. Immersive and emotional, I don't often go to the cinema, only for special films and this was very special. I think the Oscars need not look elsewhere for Best Actor and best Supporting Actor 👏👏👏 #JokerFolieADeux.

An excellent film that contains incredible cinematography with atmosphere and emotion packed into every shot. The film continues on from the events in 'Joker' and focuses on the subsequent trial while examining the reception and interaction of the Joker with society at large. While 'Joker' allowed the audience to indulge in its fantasies, the sequel directly challenges these and calls out the hypocrisy and selfishness of doing so. Much like 'Fight Club' the film does an excellent job of criticising the hollowness and hypocrisy of the violent delusions of the disaffected, all while maintaining a sympathetic view on said disaffected. Much like the ending of 'Fight Club', expect many confused and angry reactions to this film.

The film continues with the bleak and difficult subject matter from 'Joker'. As in 'Joker' Arthur's fantasies grow ever more more elaborate and violent. The film covers difficult material but remains engaging throught with well thought out and creative cinematography and well written characters full of personality and heart. Without giving anything away, while the first film allowed the audience to escape into fantastical delusion to escape the bleak subject matter, the sequel brings all this crashing back to reality, exposing those who only wish to use Arthur's suffering to further their own agendas while caring little for the real person at the heart of it.

The first movie started with him talking to social worker the second movie I believe focused on the underfunded psych awards. The cinematography was on point And beautifully done.

Watching this movie gave me a new perspective on reality stars and watching bad toxic relationships on reality TV if people really want to understand why some of these people who put themselves on reality TV and try to have a normal type of love relationship, and you question what am I doing wrong? What is wrong with these people? This is a film, that gives you the inside look of what's really going on in these peoples minds that you watch in these toxic relationships. I don't know what people expect when they saw this movie, but I enjoyed it because we saw Author when he was talking to a social worker in the very first movie. This time we see him in a poorly fund psych ward. This is what you would imagine is going on in someone's mind that has gone through so much and caused so much toxicity, it makes sense to me.

It stripped of every power fantasy from the OG joker and every fairytale between him and harley, she only cares about the joker not Arthur Fleck, which makes Arthur Fleck's being still lonely and miserable but he accepts the adoption of his fantasy by Harley because it numbs his pain and feels good.

The power fantasies are stripped of but the movie is not empty because ofthat, Arthur Fleck still expresses power as Joker.

But all of it is believable and realistic.

That is where i can't believe what's done, because stripping the jokers story of supernatural elements, without stripping the core from the joker story and adding realism, while keeping the positive elements of the power fantasy and fiction would have seem like an impossible task for me.

But it has been done so on point, so precise, that i am here mind blown after the movie.

I also don't see any inspiration for any rampage done by identifying viewers, because even while keeping the positive power elements like hot girlfriend and being a rockstar and admired, it still is empty, isolated and said.

Which is a good transcript of reality.

Every step is another burden not a reward.

I have to say again that i think this is an unbelievably hard task to accomplish, but it is also what is needed for this topic.

Brutal honesty instead of Surpression or overly done power fantasies.

This is the mature joker movie who challenges you to look deeper into yourself, your shadow.

And yes there are Jokers out there and the horrible things and situations you see in this movie are happening to them.

So as none-joker think twice if you want to lend people a fist or a helping hand. Remember his "on stage" happyface and remember his depression when he is lonely.

(The part where he becomes joker again when his sad embarrassing life is analyzed in front of the whole court is also well done psychologically. Humiliation is something which just leads to more misery and to Arthur Fleck and all the Jokers out there to become more of a monster. Don't humiliate the people when they are trying to put on their "happyface". It's a cry for help and attention.)

PS: I also like the subtle psychological clues, for example at the beginning and the end of the movie about the shadow, or the theatre about Oedipus which tell a lot about the insight the creators of the movie have about this topic.

By the way the main point of Oedipus in psychology is not a sexual relationship or killing the father but a overly controlling mother who makes her child dependant of her and helpless which leads to the oedipal dream of killing the father and to become the partner of the mother, not with the goal to sleep with her, but with the goal that she never leaves you because now you can give her also the only thing her child can't give to her. A partnership.

But dependancy leads to aggression that's why he kills her.

In reality most Matricides are also commited largely by their sons with the Oedipus Disorder.

So please don't feel disgusted about this topic if you identify with Arthur.

Throughout the movie, we might've been thinking that they will build the mountain, the highest one that everyone expects. I do not even think the ending will be like that! BRILLIANT! 🤡

The way the tone color changes every time the Joker is around or the fantasy they live in is very clever. It makes you question everything about what happened in the courtroom when the final statement happens. You can see that Arthur/Joker having a difficult moment thinking about who he is. Everyone around them just simplifies him as just Arthur or Joker, even Lee. It shows how complexion in human physiology are.

I love the movie because the point of movie was not Joker as a person but being clown in society that is waiting for someone to start anarchy and it rly show how people are next to you only when you are "something" (in this case clown), also her love is here only to show herself how she is with someone who is popular and hero in others eyes. Only after he realise he is not Joker but some random Arthur guy she leaves him... same is in real life with "heroes" and "clowns" people are here only when you are cool and when they can use you for their own benefit and promotion. Musical part is only about 20 mins of movie in total of 138min and it rly is not a musical... Him singing only shows his mental part that he signs only when he is happy and it is not often... I think generally people stick too much on Joker (DC Joker) and not on the point of what Joker represents in society and world we live in. Love it!

Joker: Folie à Deux: is nothing short of a beautifully twisted journey into the psyche. This film was not what I expected, it shattered all preconceived notions of a typical comic book adaptation. Joaquin Phoenix and Lady Gaga deliver deeply captivating performances, pulling the audience into a world that's as chaotic as it is hypnotic.

The film dives far beyond the surface, packed with subliminal messages and moments that linger long after the credits roll. It's not just about the Joker or Harley Quinn; it's a dark and intricate exploration of madness, delusion, and human frailty. There are layers of meaning here that make it more than a comic book movie, it feels like a commentary on the human condition.

This isn't a movie that will make you comfortable; instead, it challenges your perceptions, twisting familiar characters into something far more unsettling. Yet, in that discomfort lies its brilliance. Folie à Deux goes beyond expectations, presenting a hauntingly beautiful narrative that sticks with you, and pushes the boundaries of comic book storytelling in ways few films dare to attempt.

I went into this movie with the understanding that it probably wouldn't surpass the original, and I have to say I was largely satisfied with the production overall. The filmmakers did a great job maintaining the spirit of the first one, capturing much of what made it special, even if it wasn't perfect. The only real critique I have is with the pacing of the movie. It felt rushed at times but other than that I had no issue with the other aspects. People should really manage their expectations better when going into this movie. It was never gonna top the first one but in no way, shape or form did it undermine the original.

After reading some shocking reviews I went into this movie very cautiously.

Ok yes there's lots... LOTS of singing. Musical ?? (As everyone says) NO !! Lots of singing ? Yes. After 30 minutes I genuinely thought I wasn't going to get through it.

But I did.

It's very good.

DO NOT expect this to be like the first Joker. If you do, you'll hate it. Phoenix and Ga Ga and brilliant and the story makes more sense the further on it goes and draws you in.

So many people saying "what was the end all about" and "I just didn't get it".

It's really not that difficult.!

This movie is 'different'. Again, it's NOTHING like the first so don't expect it to be and you'll find yourself enjoying it.

I'm sorry I don't get the hate. I went in thinking it's going to be rubbish and it was a work of art. In a world where kids can't watch movies anymore all that watch is YouTube shorts. Or where all super hero movies are predictable oh look there's a bad guy and in the end we are going to kill him and win! This was fab. It was eerie. It was weird. It was uncomfortable it was literally art. Are people jumping on a band wagon and hating it? Or are people so closed minded they want rubbish? This is a good movie. It's like living in a weird warped warped fantasy. Maybe the haters just don't get it. I loved it I want another one. I love Arthouse and this is what it was.

Here's your review translated into English:

---

I haven't been so overwhelmed by the formula and freshness of a comic book-based film in a long time, but this one licks the comic through triple gold foil. Did I like it? Yes. Did something irritate me? Indeed. But in 10-15 years, this film will return to the internet on lists of the "TOP 10 most underrated movies ever." What is it? For me, it's a prison-courtroom drama drenched in a musical, addressing the mental issues of the protagonist, who causes a social sensation as an accidental symbol of rebellion. However, as an Arkham resident without makeup, he is dismissed and labeled a psycho deserving of the electric chair. This underlying, cynical play on the protagonist's emotions to wind him up and ignite him, creating the best version of himself in the process, is brilliantly executed - the hero's tragedy sometimes evokes a smile, sometimes consternation.

People hated the sequel because they didn't get an obvious continuation made for 200 million dollars. This sequel is precisely measured based on the ending of the first film, while also playing with the narrative through music. I recommend it because it's something totally different, ambitious (even hyper-ambitious), and devoid of the mannerisms of a typical blockbuster.

It is so refreshing to see such a production that demonstrates a complete command of the medium witha team of actors that are willing to put it all on the line. It is not for everyone, but those brave enough are in for a rare treat!

You know you are in the hands of a master film maker and a cast that gives themselves over 110% to his talent and displays their own with nor fear. I was blown away by Joaquin and Lady Gaga! It is well known that I hate classic musicals- but this is not that animal- If anything, the musical aspect truly shows the depth of what is apparently Arthur Fleck's true mania. But that 50% of the movie is awe inspiring.

Joaquin gives it all in when he turns into the vocal Joker with a mic, and the passive quite Joker-in-love when without one. His last renditioninto a pay phone is heart wrentching! I was waiting for the full-blow musical flip in the film, but it never comes.... instead we explore Arthur's mind and his new found love interest.

The addition of the venerable Brendan Gleeson as one of the old-time guards is amazing as always.

If you loved Joaquin's JOKER movie performance, you will love this film. I sincerely hope he gets an OSCAR nod. The songs are carefully dealt with in all their fashions, and the underscore is truly haunting and appropriate. There is one scene in the trailer that is not in the movie and that did bother me. This has been happening lately. But overall this is a rare movie experience.

Contrary to many reviews and opinions I've read, I actually thought this was a great film. Perhaps it's because I expected it to be filled with non-stop singing, which I feared would be terrible-but I was pleasantly surprised. The story was truly engaging, and I felt connected to the characters throughout. The performances were well-crafted, with each actor bringing something special to their role. The pacing was perfect, and the music complemented the narrative beautifully. The film takes you on a journey that keeps you invested from start to finish. I didn't feel bored for even a second. Highly recommend giving it a chance if you're skeptical like I was!

Don't be dissuaded by these negative reviews. It's a challenging, beautifully crafted film. Amazing performances all around. The cinematography is incredible. A twist on a typical comic book movie where the focus becomes the underlying theme or motivation of the character (mental illness).

Lady Gaga is phenomenal.

The use of music was ingenious. It's an internal film where the lead is forced to go because there's really no where else to go. It's a device and a smart one. It's another way to tell a story that gets closer to the emotion then you might with dialogue.

I loved it. Bravo all involved.

If Todd Phillips and Scott Silver had to make a second movie for joker, this was a perfekt way to do it. Without saying much, this movie really comments on all the criticism the first one got. The ones that dont like the new one, is exactly a point in it self. And I fully understand, because the first one was phenomenal, so people are sad about ruining the first movie, that's less clear in its message, and therefore more up to the individual and personal analysis. The second one is way more clear, and that might be annoying for some. Anywaayy, please try to understand the message it tries to prove, you will enjoy it a lot more!!! And people just love to hate musicals, thats all. The hate here is too much man. I mean come ooooooon. It is great!!!!

I feel compelled to defend this film, given how its brilliance has been overlooked by those expecting a typical comic book adaptation.

This is not just a movie about a villain-it's an intricate exploration of Arthur Fleck's mental illness, psychosis, and dissociation. His character's fragility is at the heart of his journey, showing how society can break someone suffering from mental illness, driving them toward a darker identity.

The glamorization of his descent symbolizes something much more ominous. Arthur was never intended to be the calculating, sociopathic Joker we're familiar with, but rather a tragic figure who becomes the catalyst for the "real" Joker. The decision to frame the movie as a musical mirrors his fractured mind, turning this film into a psychological odyssey instead of a straightforward origin story.

The Joker's backstory was always mysterious, deliberately chaotic, and constantly shifting-this film embraces that concept and executes it masterfully.

AND AS IMPORTANTLY!! How can anyone watch Joaquin Phoenix's performance and think this film deserves anything less than three stars? SERIOUSLY?!?

***!***SPOILERS BELOW***!***

His portrayal of Arthur, with every raw emotion etched into his expressions and every sung note, is nothing short of Oscar-worthy.

Yes, his death is truly heartbreaking, making it difficult not to deduct points, as it feels like an immense loss. However, if this is the conclusion, and we as viewers are meant to bridge the gap between Joaquin's Joker and Heath Ledger's through our own imagination-two PEAK performances in their own right-this film unquestionably deserves a perfect five.

But that's just my OPINION yo!!

Wow!

It's surprising how many people assumed Joker 2 would be bad without actually seeing it. Hearing all the negativity made me more eager to watch, and I was blown away. The movie is deep, with brilliant acting and stunning cinematography. Phoenix deserves a Best Actor nomination. It left me with so many thoughts-nothing is black and white, and there's always another perspective.

Maybe there was 1-2 songs to much but with besides that the music did a great job telling the story even deeper. With that said it was a great movie and the perfect sequel to the first film. I can highly recommend this movie!

Actually, that works as a recap of the plot, but I mean the insipid and arrogant reviews. 5.3? Are you kidding me?

I loved Joaquin's original Joker and this is a profoundly meaningful dive deeper into his personal trauma and the emotional space around him. Lada Gaga's Lee Quinzel is brilliant. I admit, I'd have paid just to hear her sing her bits here. But both give nuanced, textured, emotional performances.

As for the music, if anything it's subtle and organic. I don't hate musicals, but Folie à Deux manifests none of the typical musical contrivance. Hell, I'd have been okay if it leaned in there. But people's whining about the music is off-base, to say the least.

I suppose it "lacks" the kind of violence and "action" a philistine consumer might desire, but I found its pacing and introspective thoughtfulness well-matched to the material. Go play a first-person shooter, if that's what gets your rocks off. Are the rest of us not entitled to the substantive nature of a movie like this every now and then.

What people seem to hate about the movie is that it's not what they expected and doesn't conform to mainstream sensibilities. As far as I'm concerned, that's part of why it's so beautiful.

The thing I "didn't like" about the movie is that it often made me sad and frustrated about the human condition. But I kinda think that's the point.

I felt really depressed before I saw the movie because there were so many negative reviews, even from film experts I really appreciate. However, I wanted to form my own opinion. Today, I watched the film in the cinema, and it was GREAT. The film took me deep inside. Many call it lazy; I call it a masterpiece. If people say the first Joker was great but the second wasn't, they didn't understand the first Joker at all. If you don't like both Joker films, I can accept that, but don't say the first was great and the second wasn't. If that's the case, it's just not your genre. Go watch Harry Potter and the stone of mainstream! Joker 2 has an outstanding character, but maybe you have to be a bit of a freak like I am to appreciate this piece of art. It was great, but I can only give it 9 stars because the powerful mainstream is overshadowing my true opinion!"

This is one of the greatest movies ever made about the collective human subconscious driving fate. The acting is very subtle and personal, the script is very well written. The characters have their completely parallel worlds, and the result is a mix of fate. Exceptional high IQ movie, even the musical parts increased the emotional investment of the audience. It's basically a prequel to the real Joker character and it needs multiple viewings to really get why picking up the crown is not for the weak. Overall an underrated movie that reminds me of the psychological dramas of the 90s. Cannot recommend it enough!

This film is definitely misunderstood.

I love how it explores the complexities and turmoil of mental health. The psychosis of the Joker - the gregarious, unrestrained showman and fantasist - is perfectly represented by the musical level, with the dark pain of Arthur Fleck languishing in a world without music and flamboyance. The two levels are bridged by Arthur's desperate infatuation with the equally disturbed Lee.

It's feels like the bad reviews stem from a misunderstanding of mental health and also the narrative devices of the musical. I strongly suspect that in time this film will be recognised as a cult classic.

I loved the movie. As a huge comic movie fan I too was dissapointed that is was not the sequel it was expected to be. But, if you just watch the movie as cinema enjoyer, you will see a very poetic, gritty, musical drama. And this was greatly written as a possible sequel still. Even when it was not expected to be like this. Todd Howard still made a wonderfull movie. The musical parts give the movie a unique style. It is a beautiful written movie, that again shows a lot of what can go on in the minds of people who are misunderstood. Also again great acting from Joaquin Phoenix.

The sequel we did not deserved, we still got.

"Joker: Folie à Deux" is a film that surprises with its boldness and originality, with Lady Gaga delivering an impeccable performance as Harley Quinn. Her vocal and acting talent blends perfectly with the dark, psychological atmosphere of the film, making the character complex and captivating.

Gaga skillfully balances vulnerability and madness, offering moments of pure emotional intensity. Her scenes with Joaquin Phoenix are engaging and full of tension, enhanced by musical numbers that never feel out of place but instead add a unique touch to the story. A film that stands out thanks to Gaga's performance, an essential addition to this fresh take on the world of Joker.

First things first, I walked out of a film I bloody loved. I've heard complaints about why people disliked it, and all I have to say about those complaints is that they are just dumb. I'm not going to talk about the complaints because they may evoke spoilers, but needless to say I massively disagree with them.

Secondly, for anyone worried, it's a film with musical elements. It is NOT a fully fledged musical.

The film is about Arthur Fleck and his relationship with Harley during his criminal trial for the events of the first film. The trial story, while central to the film, is the lesser of two parts. This is a film about a relationship between two mentally unstable oddballs and how it impacts them and their lives throughout.

Phoenix continues his awesome work as the central figure, trying to navigate a world that doesn't understand him, all while knowing that there are people who idolise him because of his crimes. The effort he puts into this character make me a little ashamed of the lack of effort I ever put into any of my own acting. This performance is just as strong as the first film. Gaga is a really interesting take on Harley. All of the base elements we love about her are there but Gaga plays her so differently to anyone else. I throughly enjoyed this version of Miss Quinzel.

Todd Phillips has done a great job continuing the story of Arthur Fleck, while doing so in a way that feels really different to the original, but never (for me), in a bad way. The cinematography, sound and direction all blend together seamlessly to create a vision where reality and madness intertwined, and at times become difficult to tell apart.

Overall? I loved this film. Is it flawless? No, but it was (again, for me) pretty damn close. It's a DC Elseworlds story that features musical elements. It's simply not going to be for everyone. It was for me...4.5/5...

I'm stunned at some reviews of this film and wonder if some reviewers are missing the point.

This is a study in mental illness and society's reaction to it and celebrity generally. Thought Joaquin Phoenix's Arthur Fleck/Joker was mesmerising again and surprised at Lady Gaga's acting talent. Enjoyed Brendan Gleason as one of Arthur's guards and was particularly impressed by Leigh Gill as Gary Puddles. This is not a musical either; the songs more of an explanation or illustration of inner turmoil.

This is a film definitely worth seeing but do what we did and rewatch the first film before you go.

To me this film seems like a triumph, a great victory, I greatly admire the courage of its director, its scriptwriters, its stars, The great and bold Joaquin Phoenix, The wonderful singer Lady Gaga, the beautiful Catherine Keener, and as always Brendan Gleeson is a marvel on the screen.

I am very sorry that people are not understanding this ugly jewel, that they do not accept Todd Phillips s vision without compromise, and that they do not understand Larry Sher s masterful use of color.

However, what I enjoyed most about this film was its resounding denunciation of the profound iniquity of its predecessor.

The movie Joker: Folie à Deux presents a dark & deep dive into the mental health issues of Arthur Fleck and Harleen Quinzel. Every single moment of insanity turns into a great & dark musical number. The soundtrack is 10/10 and the performance of both Joaquin and Gaga is incredible - you can feel their delusion and madness everytime they start performing another song. The movie is deffinitely not for everybody, but the hate on it seems really forced. If you liked the first one for the right reasons, you will deffinitely enjoy the second part as well. I wish some of the leaked scenes made the final cut.

Who actually thinks, that they hire Lady Gaga, in a movie with no signing? The people who have walked out of this movie, saw the title, had a brain shutdown, went to the movies, did not like it, beacause there is singing, walked out.

The movie is great, not the best, but absolutley not horrible. The signing makes sense to me, it's in his head and in his little boble of fantasies.

The only thing I think is a bit «staged» is the constant refrences to music, like the guards say «its showtime» and the over explanation as to why there is music in the movie. The music should have just stayed a fantasy in the Joker's head.

Lady Gaga does a fantastisk job btw, and so does Phoenix aswell.

Have an open mind, there is not 40 songs in the movie, like some articles have claimed, threre is maybe 10% singing, the story is not told with singing. And to the people that does not like musicals, don't go to a musical and do a bit of research before you go to the movies.

The first joker film , I really never took too. I watched it 3 or 4 times , but I found the obvious, and wildley triggering narrative too much . I didn't like it , but found it a piece of art that was still a solid film. I found this better. However , unless you have experienced mental health on a level that is massively severe, i doubt for 1 second you will even begin to grasp this . I found this way , way better than the first . But , I've served time in psychiciat wards. I've been around the comics , I've suffered delusions , supposedly, and ultimately didn't meet the girl of my dreams , blah blah. I watched this with a friend who I was helping (as I'm a qualified therapist now) and. We have just had sectioned and is staying with me. We both found it , 'brave' completely mis interpreted and totally apt to those born in the system. Brave film, completely mis understood. Awesome piece of film.

This film is fantastic.

The acting, the story, the musical elements are all great and all used to take us on a deep diver into the chaotic and fractured mind of Arthur Fleck. It's an exceptional exploration into how a character/persona created to help a man cope with mental illness goes on to influence the disenfranchised masses of Gotham. The Harley Quinn plot is great, sad & heartbreaking.

All leading to the ending which perfectly bridges the gap from Arthur Flecks Joker, to the violent and brutal Joker Heath Ledger so fantastically portrayed.

Phoenix & Gaga are exceptional and I would expect some academy award nods. The cinematography & score are top draw too.

Don't get the hate this film is getting. I think people are completely missing the point. Go in open minded and you won't be disappointed.

The story of Joker and Lee got me crying a lot! Gaga is so amazing! She played so well that I felt in love with her character! There was just a perfect amount of music in the film. It was a real pleasure to watch the whole movie in the theater. I'll definitely will rewatch it to see more details and understand it better. Beautiful picture, great cast, amazing music, isn't that what we all need? I guess this time Gaga showed the crazy side of hers, and it was good! "Let's give people what they want!'" No more words! This is the best movie of 2024. Lady Gaga should definitely get an Oscar for that role.

The story is more complicated than most of us was expecting. The only thing I want to say is those of you who were disappointed by the story are just like those people in the court that leave the room after Arthur says it was simply him, that he didn't want to do all hi's done.

We don't want to see about a human being that suffer the mental illness, we want to see one more show based on comics. I think the second part speaks more about society than the first one.

The end of the movie shows that now whoever can be Joker, whoever can do it the way he wants, but especially whoever can commit a crime behind the mask.

While the first "Joker" was a good psychological thriller drama - I really didn't see on forehand how a follow-up would be super interesting or even possible to deliver in a good way - I was floored by this demented masterpiece. Even darker than the first movie, but balancing with the journeys into the main character's imagination. A radical move back to real international cinema of the golden days. Very much anti Hollywood in general but very anti streamline cinema in particular. Yes, it qualifies as a musical - but remember, this is about a demented entertainer. The entertainer who puts on a mask to survive and to be enough in a harsh reality. A beautiful piece of cinema.

The movie delves deep into the heart of what the Joker represents-the embodiment of the marginalized and the miserable. In a way that echoes the grim humanism of Hugo's novels, Joker captures the unsteady decline of a fragile mind, using subtle visual cues and increasingly eerie music to mirror the unraveling psyche. When reality comes crashing down, it doesn't hold back.

Joaquin Phoenix delivers a phenomenal performance. His portrayal of the Joker is haunting, with every glance and gesture speaking volumes where words fail. The story is a tragic one, a slow-motion catastrophe that feels preventable-but only if everyone had been someone different that who they want to be. Instead, we witness the train wreck of a life that leaves the viewer to decide how much of this is due to the nature, and how much is due to nurture.

One of the most interesting aspects is the depiction of Harley Quinn. She's no longer just an unhinged sidekick or eye candy. Here, she's portrayed as a manipulative, toxic thrill-seeker, a wealthy woman who relishes deepening the wounds, daring to think she is experiencing the same trauma as the least fortunate. It's a fresh take that deepens her character.

If there's one misstep, it's the continued demonization of people with split personalities, a common trope in films that could have been handled with more nuance. Nonetheless, it remains a powerful exploration of mental health, societal neglect, and the thin line between victim and villain.

Almost didn't go based on the reviews but we had already bought our tickets. Thank goodness we went and saw it on the big screen!

Joachim Phoenix is arguably the greatest actor of all time in my books. This performance was one of his best that I have seen. Simply amazing!

We loved the cinematography, the direction and the script. There was nothing to dislike about the movie in our books (4 of us thought the same) Lady Gaga is a very good actor. She was the perfect person for this role alongside Phoenix.

People complain about the music - we had no idea why as it complimented the story line perfectly.

I honestly think that people have been influenced by the negativity of the critics. Go see it for yourself and enjoy acting like you rarely see in Hollywood movies nowadays.

You cannot watch it seperately from the first part and together they show a developement kind of like the first two movies in Nolan's Batman- trilogy. Whereas the first part is the awakening of the Joker, the second part explains the ups and downs of Joker losing his laugh and completely losing it. I loved the folie à deux, because it made me feel the torture of Joker physically. And yes, I am too empathic and I can understand what drove Joker and actually why he cannot meet Harley's or his henchmens' expectations. He never wanted to start a revolution, well until now. I sure hope for an end of a trilogy, but the end of the movie is also fullfilling.

Lady Gaga did a very good job, exceeding my expectations. Joaquin did an amazing job. The Harvey Dent character was underdeveloped. Did I miss the coin? We see the face damage, but was it enough to turn him to Two-Face as in Detective Comics #66 (August 1942), where he appeared first.

What is a folie à deux. Wikipedia says: Folie à deux (French for 'madness of two'),also known as shared psychosis or shared delusional disorder (SDD), is a psychiatric syndrome in which symptoms of a delusional belief are "transmitted" from one individual to another.

Lee and Arthur shared their depression even the desire to exit the stage. But in my opinion the psychosis spread to the other inmates of Arkham...

I couldn't think of a better follow up to 2019's Joker. It was sublime. Think about what made Joker a success. It subverted expectations by giving us a different look at what Joker could be. It was original. Joker: Folie a Deux is, again, original but unique in presenting the fantasy world that Arthur Fleck has created and then blurs the lines by bringing Joker to life when he most needs him. Gaga is magical. Although we've come to expect amazing things from her voice she brings a subtleness to Harley that shows the over the top version has it's place but isn't always appropriate. Joaquin Phoenix brings it again and although we had less compulsive laughing than Joker (1) we had an even more nuanced performance that gave a glimpse into what mental illness and the blurred line of the human condition means in a world that is constantly unexpected, to say the least. He makes you want to root for his character despite the awefulness he contributes to a world that is somehow more evil than he is. Todd Phillips gave us the most beautifully directed movie of his career. Whereas Joker (2019) was a heavy homage to movie of the 70s and early 80s, specifically from Scorsese's Taxi Driver and less obviously The King of Comedy. The sequel reveals a more original story and concept that fits with the first but stands strong as a second. Audiences and critics that scorn the movie for being different may not remember what made Joker so amazing in the first place. Its originality, story, characters, scenes, designs, shots, etc. Made 2019's Joker a success and we should appreciate 2024's Joker: Folie A Duex for the same reasons.

I came into this movie expecting it to suck like everyone had been saying and walked out not only being surprised, but actually loving it. I feel bad for people who missed the message and see it as a flop.

All the "normies" who think this is a musical are actually just getting a glimpse into the mind of someone with mental illness and the way their mind creates fantasy. In this movie we see a new side of Arthur as he experiences someone wanting him FOR THE FIRST TIME IN HIS LIFE". It's no wonder he feels like singing.

And additionally I love the idea that the Joker isn't a person but a movement. It's a terrifying wild fire that Arther set ablaze that is rooted in chaos. It's not about Arthur.

While the first Joker film was a deep character study focusing on isolation, despair, and the violence that arises from a fractured society, its sequel ventures into an entirely different thematic realm, centering on love. The decision to introduce musical elements, although bold and risky, blends seamlessly into the narrative and enhances the film's unique atmosphere. This time, we witness a more romantic side of Arthur, whose emotional depth stands in stark contrast to the demanding and domineering character of Lee. The interplay between the two leads is compelling, offering a fresh take on both characters. Sadly, the film's negative reviews seem misplaced and do not do justice to the final product, which delivers a thought-provoking and artistically.

"Joker: Folie à Deux" is nothing short of mesmerizing. The sequel to Todd Phillips' 2019 masterpiece takes the original's gritty, psychological intensity and elevates it into a bold, operatic experience that's both visually stunning and emotionally powerful. This film is not just a follow-up-it's an evolution.

Joaquin Phoenix once again proves why he's one of the best actors of our time. His portrayal of Arthur Fleck/Joker is even more layered and complex here. Phoenix captures the torment, fragility, and madness of the character with chilling precision, making it impossible to look away. The addition of Lady Gaga as Harley Quinn is brilliant. She not only holds her own alongside Phoenix but also brings a fresh, electrifying dynamic to the screen. Her transformation is gradual yet powerful, and their twisted chemistry is captivating.

The musical elements, which could have been a risky choice, actually work incredibly well. Phillips intertwines musical sequences with the narrative in a way that feels organic, yet hallucinatory. It's a striking blend of realism and fantasy, reflecting the fractured mental states of its characters. The songs don't just enhance the mood-they're part of the storytelling itself.

Visually, Joker: Folie à Deux is stunning. The cinematography is rich with colors and contrasts, capturing both the decaying world of Gotham and the vivid, fever-dream world inside the characters' minds. Every shot feels meticulously crafted, with a haunting score that lingers long after the credits roll.

While the film is dark, it's not without moments of dark humor and poignant commentary on society's treatment of mental illness and its underclass. It builds on the themes of the first movie but takes them in a new direction that feels fresh, daring, and unafraid to challenge the audience.

In terms of pacing, it may not be for everyone-Joker: Folie à Deux is slow-burn, with an emphasis on character and atmosphere over traditional action. But for those who appreciate psychological drama and character study, this is a thrilling journey into the depths of madness.

Verdict: Joker: Folie à Deux is a rare sequel that expands on the original while standing firmly on its own. Phoenix and Gaga deliver career-defining performances, and Todd Phillips crafts a film that's as beautiful as it is disturbing. A must-watch for fans of the first film, and for anyone who appreciates daring, visionary cinema.

The plot is a vehicle for the message and theme about comedy as a coping method and the disappointment others experience when seeing the real person behind the mask. The musical psychosis is the delivery mechanism. Writer-director Todd Phillips has been a comedian/filmmaker in Hollywood for many years and broke from that role with the first Joker. His career and feelings are on display again with this sequel that chooses art over cheap thrills.

It all makes sense if you think of it that way and not as a comic book movie that should continue the legend of the Joker.

Great acting and art direction. 4/5 because some of the songs were too long and uninspired, but overall a great experience if you go in with an open mind.

I thought it was excellent. Without giving too many spoilers away. The courtroom drama and it's finale were absolutely gripping and right on point for our times. Don't believe the bandwagon of hate, go see it for yourself and keep an open mind. The chemistry between GAGA and Fleck works beautifully, and what is real or imagined is explicitly shown throughout. However, even aspects of this are open to interpretation.

You're gonna love it, or hate it. Just don't listen to what the paid critics say, or the bitcoin youtuber.

If you love a psychological drama, with an unhinged story this is for you.

I absolutely Loved this Joker film and I'll probably see it a few more times to fully appreciate its pure darkness. It's a film about the human experience and struggle, not all blue skies and puppy dog dreams. Extremely thought provoking.

The acting was incredible, Joaquin Phoenix should be, at the very least, nominated for best actor. Lady Gaga killed it too, I'm so impressed with the roles she chooses. It almost seems as though this script was written with her in mind.

It's essentially a very dark theatrical musical, many broadway aficionados will appreciate the evolution of this musical masterpiece with an immensely challenging topic made for the big screen. I laughed and cried. I Loved the duets, it seemed like Gaga almost had to notch down her musical prowess in order to make her character believable yet it was a beautiful match to Joaquin's musical ability.

Ignore the one sided reviews and go see this film....

I really enjoyed Joker (2019) and it's my favorite movie by Todd Phillips, but it is also a movie that shouldn't have gotten a sequel. Unfortunately, it was announced that this movie was coming out and I was puzzled by it. Then, all of the reviews came in and it has been divisive, even more than the original. So, I just finished watching Joker: Folie a Deux (2024) and while I had a great time with the movie, I also have to say that we were right about not making a sequel to Joker (2019) in the first place.

Positives for Joker: Folie a Deux (2024): I will say that the movie's plot centering around Arthur Fleck being on trial for what happened in the first movie is very interesting. Todd Phillip's directing is still on point in this movie. Joaquin Phoenix is still great as Arthur Fleck/The Joker and he is even crazier in this movie. I also really liked Lady Gaga as Lee Quinzel and her dynamic with Joaquin Phoenix is very entertaining. The musical numbers are pretty good for what they are. And finally, the final act of this movie has some entertaining moments.

Negatives for Joker: Folie a Deux (2024): There isn't a reason for why this movie should exist because the first movie was designed to not have sequels, but Warner Bros. Didn't get that their heads. I also don't understand why the movie was even marketed as a musical in the first place. And finally, the last 20 minutes of the movie did not sit well with me and it definitely confirmed that this movie was indeed entirely pointless.

Overall, Joker: Folie a Deux (2024) has a lot of entertainment value to it, but it is another one of those sequels that should not exist.

This film is visually striking and emotionally charged. The animated introduction sets a vibrant tone. The cinematography is simply beautiful, with rich colors, dynamic close-ups.

The editing is excellent, especially the slow-motion sequences and the parallel editing during the intense court trial scenes. Seeing it on IMAX was an even more immersive experience due to the aspect ratio changes, which is a unique visual storytelling technique that I loved.

What makes this film feel different from a typical sequel is that it acts like an epilogue. It explores Arthur's imagination, contrasting how he sees his world and how society views him. The ending is devastating and ironic, using upbeat music in a way that feels intentionally contradictory to the film's darker tones, which left me with mixed emotions.

Hearing the Joker theme again was refreshing; I appreciated the variations and layers added to it throughout the film. While it repeats, each iteration feels intentional and impactful.

The music selection was fantastic. In this film, music feels like Arthur's lifeline - it's his way of finding hope. His emotions are powerfully channeled through music; it strengthens the film's atmosphere.

Sound design is one of the standout elements. It's so well-mixed, using techniques like sound muffles and silence at the right moments, which makes the visual storytelling even more impactful.

Joaquin Phoenix delivers yet another masterful performance as Arthur Fleck, bringing out the complexity of the character. Lady Gaga, while a bit odd due to her recognizable voice, decently fits into the role of Harley Quinn. I initially had my doubts, but she worked well for this interpretation of the character.

One minor disappointment was that some scenes shown in the trailer didn't make it into the final cut. Those moments could have added something extra, but overall, it didn't take away too much from my enjoyment.

Overall, this is not an action-packed film but a slow, dark, and thoughtful exploration of Arthur Fleck's character. Todd Phillips shows a lot of experimentation in this film, and I admire his bold vision. I'd comfortably give it an 8/10 for its artistic vision, performances, and emotional depth.

First, Joker: Folie a Deux is NOT a musical so do not believe everything you read or hear. Second, yes, there is music and singing as there is with any other movie. Third, this movie is great! It picks up from the first movie and goes in a direction many people missed. I was not a fan of this movie when it first started and then I understood everything, except the ending. If you don't get the movie, you just won't get it. There are plenty of references that point to what is going on and why. This is a Joker movie that is overshadowed by negativity and people are missing out on a great movie and great acting. If you don't know the Joker character, then you have not been paying attention at all.

I went to this film with my son and we are both fans of the DC franchise. After the film I had a conversation with the cinema manager. She told me the film had not done well at her box office although she liked it. I asked, so what was it that people disliked. She said that it was a musical. Was it? I thought it was a journey and exploration of the mind and personality of an abused child who as a man was schizophrenic - a term never used in the film. We both thought the musical interventions were entirely inappropriate with some marvellous set pieces and songs, well delivered, which helped to illustrate the mind of Fleck and his place in his world. The performances were excellent and styling of everything was top tier. For those that said they didn't like it I would say you just don't get Arthur or how his mind works. Try it again.

The cinematography, the acting, the details - brilliant! At first I was a little bothered by things like cartoons or songs, but once got past the "face value" and started reading into metaphors, lighting, angles, went deeper into the WHYs, I saw everything connecting. And from there on, the songs spoke so much more, especially the lyrics. I almost did not want to blink the entire movie not to miss any details that complement the story. It kept me on my toes where I was second guessing if what I understand is in fact how it was intended. Not sure if I got all the answers, but I'm sure they're there. Definitely would go again to see the details I missed. This is not some simple "friday night movie" and I think it might be too deep for some people.

Brilliant! Carries on the story of the Joker perfectly. The musical numbers fit seamlessly into the film and are brilliantly preformed. The only weak link is probably Lady Gaga, her vocals in the songs are weak compared to Phoenix. It's a great addition to the DC universe and adds to the lore of the Joker smartly. The first movie was pretty good but this surpasses it for drama and suspense. If anyone wants an introduction to the character of the Joker and his motives and personality, this is the perfect vehicle for that. Completely re-watchable. Can't recommend this enough to DC fans. Groundbreaking and bold.

This movie was perfect - even better than the first film, in my opinion, which is a tall order to meet. I especially thought that Lady Gaga stood out as Harleen "Lee" Quinzel. Perfect. No notes. Her chemistry with the obviously-incredible Joaquin Phoenix - who won an Academy Award for his first turn as Arthur "The Joker" Fleck - is immaculate. Who knew they would mesh so well together? My only critique would be: there isn't enough of her in the film. Hopefully they remedy this by giving her her own spin-off movie. There is one scene in particular that stands out among the rest... Those who have seen the movie will know the one that I'm talking about.

Great job to all involved!

The movie of the year! Lady Gaga is incredible, her character, her performance alongside Joaquin is out of this world, I was really looking forward to seeing this movie, I hope they win the Oscar!

The movie of the year! Lady Gaga is incredible, her character, her performance alongside Joaquin is out of this world, I was really looking forward to seeing this movie, I hope they win the Oscar!

The movie of the year! Lady Gaga is incredible, her character, her performance alongside Joaquin is out of this world, I was really looking forward to seeing this movie, I hope they win the Oscar!

The movie of the year! Lady Gaga is incredible, her character, her performance alongside Joaquin is out of this world, I was really looking forward to seeing this movie, I hope they win the Oscar!

A movie about mentally ill person failed by the system, in the Batman universe, in the POV of Joker, singing and dancing in the rain. If you didn't expect this movie, not sure what you expected. Very well executed. They pull the rug from under the audience at the end, I think that turned most people off. Joker POV movie, with room to move on afterwards. Watch the first one before rolling into this one, it makes total sense. Better than the French Olympics opening, makes just as much sense. Someone nominate this for an award, they'll be looking back on this one as it's own genre. Nailed the late 70s early 80s psych ward feel. With songs.

Just watched Joker: Folie á Deux.... Wow...wow wow wow wow. The people that didn't understand this film really need to watch something other than blockbuster mainstream media. This was THE BEST movie I have seen ALL YEAR. As someone that has struggled with pretty serious mental health disorders their whole life, the first film really hit me. If you paid attention in the first film you would know that Arthur's uses music to escape his reality...Folie á Deux actually showed those fantasies he was experiencing. I have always used music to help me cope with life so I understood this incredible artistic choice that Todd Phillips and Joaquin made on a visceral level.

There were so many incredible artistic choices made in this film that blew me away. It was soooo beautifully shot. The acting was incredible. The set design. The sound design. It all weaved together perfectly. The opening is a cartoon of Joker that perfectly set up how the film was going to go. There's an incredible shot of Arthur being walked through the rain by guards and from the front you see black umbrellas, then they do an overhead shot that shows rainbow umbrellas and that shot immediately had me hooked into the story.

I love Joaquin Phoenix because he has ALWAYS made bold choices as an actor. He has always strayed away from mainstream sterilized roles and scripts and chosen to take roles that make you think. And I respect that so much. If you're a cinephile, do not listen to the negative reviews of this film. Go see it...go see it right now!

And as a bonus, I listened to Lady Gaga's companion album 'Harlequin' when it came out and I loved it. But I was confused by some of the song choices. After watching the movie I love the album even more. Every song chosen was absolutely perfect.

My take on Joker Foile à Deux keeps the same vibe as the predecessor. A cautionary tale of one's struggle with sanity. When you push someone so far they will break. In a sad dark world the only thing one may say is we have song and dance, understanding this I completely see the genius in making it in to a musical. But this is not a happy ending movie and or feel good time. Extremely sad and maybe that's what we all need to see to just treat one another with a kind word once in a while. Wow the performances was amazing written beautifully. It really doesn't deserve a horrible reviews it's been giving.

It's less of a Scorsese remake, more original, darker and is frankly better than the first one.

It's a shame that people are going to miss out on this film due to what seems like an agenda. Too many film makers are hung out to dry for not putting out the same film twice and trying something different.

It requires some thought and maybe a few watches to completely understand. But it has been completely misunderstood and deserves a better reaction.

Phoniex gives a deeper performance this time around and the musical segments do serve a greater purpose. Lady Gaga does a fine job as well along with Gleeson.

Amazing Movie! I think it went over alot of people's head. If you put yourself in Arthur's shoes and try to understand the complex feelings, it hits the needle on the head! Plus they both sing amazing, what a great duo. Alot of people's are saying it had no story or where was the story. Are you kidding me.... Joker is a complex mentally Ill character, there's ALOT of complex feelings that go into understanding a character like that. And that's where the story developments and better understanding of the complexity of the Joker.

Arthurs feelings of finally having someone who wants him, Cue the first song and man what big feelings were those, Almost brought me to tears. Then comes the complex feelings of wanting to be this person everyone wants (Joker) but kinda tired of it all, tired of being angry and hating everything. Which is bought on by Harley cause all he feels like he needs is her not this anger and hatred and reminder of what sad life he's had. But....... dum dum dum.... Harley ain't want him unless he wants to burn it to the ground with her. And the ending....oh man... I feel like it can lead up to the dark knight situation. Picture this he goes to the hospital realizes that if he ain't got Harley might as well burn it all down, takes advantage of all the people who will do his bidding and burn Gotham . They left it wide open for many possibilities. Point blank if you missed this movie you need to read a chapter on emotional intelligence and then rewatch. It'll all click.

I heard a lot this movie was a "musical", but clearly people don't know what a musical is anymore.

The minute I saw them signing I knew it was all in his head it's so obvious and pointed out it's one of his delusions. I loved this movie the way it references to the mistreatment of people who are ill and the way people view them when it comes to their breaking point, as well as the system failing to protect them from the trauma they face as children that would obviously affect them growing up. I think people over hated this film imo people don't know how to actually watch a movie. Media literacy is dead I suggest you all watch this movie again with some empathy and logic. This isn't some "action" movie with badass joker it's an actually joker who suffers from his disorder and trauma.

The first film clearly portrayed the essence of the Joker, a fragile figure with certain limitations. Harley Quinn saw in him a relentless leader, without remorse, a symbol of courage for a disillusioned society. However, as the cracks in his conviction began to show, Harley's fascination gradually faded. Vengeance does not elevate us above those who harm us. The film speaks to an audience no longer concerned with justice, but with retribution, an audience without dreams or a future, whose only hope now lies in the hands of a new Joker-one who, unlike Arthur Fleck, will know no regret, Knock, Knock!

Most comic book films are shallow and empty of feeling. The first joker broke that mould to giving us a deeper connection with the character.

Joker 2 hits in just that way again, I was rooting for Arthur every moment. I felt happy, I felt empty, I felt warmth, I felt. The point of the film for me was not action or to watch a fantasy adventure, the point was to connect with the Arthur and Harley.

The musical and surreal aspects add warmness and escapism to the films depressing themes, which is exactly what Arthur is experiencing; it is another way which we connect with the character.

The film feels like the shawshank redemption meets la-la land meets miracle on 34th street. If you like that and give it a chance, you are the right audience for this film. Unfortunately, I don't think a majority of the gotham audience are the target here and I believe that's whats causing these brutal reviews. Joaquin, Gaga and Brendan put on incredible performances and should be proud of what they have created. This film and the first will be classics one day when we look back, and Im glad the two are so lovingly crafted.

Do not play around with myths and icons. Andrew Dominik's Blonde has been partially marked with the sceal of infamy for the same reason.

"Joker : Folie à Deux" is a brilliant movie. I could read in other reviews :" A slap in the face of the Joker fans", "A waste of time and money", "An insult to fans intelligence". An insult to fans intelligence? No. On the contrary, it is an insult to fans stupidy, their intellectual, narrative, dramatic pavlovian reflexes. The "Joker" movie was not warmly welcomed by all DC fans because it also twisted Batman mythology's arm. But, the story, its structure, the drama crescendo was classic. Phillips and Phoenix chose another path this time. Against all plain expectations and odds. And that, for most, is unforgivable. Would a "classic sequel" have been a bad choice? With an adolescent Batman (many probablly dreamt about that) or God knows what? Of course not. But once again, it is simply not the choice that was made. And I thank director and main actor(s) to have made that decision. It gives us a crepuscular movie, reflecting in its direction and editing the madness of a man, for whom songs is a "mental" way of illuminating a desperate life, a way brought by a woman singing, the first time he sees her. Fleck will try to hang on to love in order to, out of darkness, come back to light. It is also the portrait of a man who wants to escape madness, and might pay several prices for that. "Joker : Folie à Deux" is a darker love story, an unusual courtroom movie, barely a musical in fact, a bright movie, full of emotions also. I'm not gonna go into details in order not to spoil anyone, but it shows a sense of subtlety all the way. Yes, definitely more difficult to savor than the first one. So what? Don't you enjoy the pain that goes with practising your favorite sport? A major studio gave us an unexpected movie 5 years ago. And instead of repeating the same pattern, the studio has been brave enough to give us another unexpected movie. Audience should make the intellectual effort to refrain from projecting onto a movie everything they expect it to be or not to be, and enjoy what its makers want to tell us. And see all its beauty. Hats off!

I walked into Folie à Deux with a heavy heart, bracing myself after reading the crushing reviews here. Yet, to my utter astonishment, what unfolded on screen was nothing short of breathtaking. It was as if I had seen an entirely different film than those who gave it a single star-ONE?! Are you kidding me?!

The story-oh yes, there is a story-was not just one, but a cascade of narratives, each more tragic than the last.

It's the story of a man thrust into fame for being something he never was.

The story of a society so beaten, they seek solace in a broken soul to lead them.

It's the brutal tale of mental illness, suffocating under the iron grip of a police state.

The story of power, corrupted and abused.

A surreal (and, yes, a bit too musical) story of an abused soul encountering someone having hybristophilia.

And the most gut-wrenching story of all: a system that not only failed him at every turn but drove him to the brink, punishing him for snapping instead of healing the wound at its core, addressing the underlying issue, the system itself.

This isn't just the story of one man; it's the story of all of us. And that's the tragic brilliance-it's not a comic book fantasy. It's a reflection of our world, raw and terrifying in its truth.

I could go on about the brilliance of the acting, the haunting soundtrack, the stunning cinematography-each element, flawless. But honestly, that goes without saying. This movie is greatness, pure and simple.

Joker: Folie à Deux transcends the boundaries of a typical sequel and delves even deeper into the fractured psyche of Arthur Fleck. Todd Phillips brilliantly merges psychological horror with musical elements to create a haunting yet captivating experience. Joaquin Phoenix's performance is once again electrifying-his portrayal of the Joker is layered, complex, and disturbingly human, while Lady Gaga's presence as Lee Quinzel is nothing short of a revelation.

The film's use of color, sound, and choreography transforms Gotham into an almost dreamlike, chaotic landscape that mirrors Arthur's unraveling mind. Every scene feels meticulously crafted, pulling the audience into the swirling vortex of the Joker's insanity. The bold narrative choices pay off spectacularly, making Folie à Deux a daring, compelling continuation that both complements and elevates the original.

This is a film that will linger long after the credits roll, offering no easy answers but leaving viewers with a profound sense of awe and unease. A true triumph of storytelling and artistry-simply a must-watch... for non-simpletons.

While I see some people don't like this movie. I loved it. I think the musical aspect was used in a very smart way to show the alternate personality of Arthur that is Joker.

I think we are bombarded with nonsensical movies nowadays and movies like Wolverine vs Deadpool which have very little intellectual thought put into it does well and Folie a Deux has a much lower rating.

To me it shows the reality of this world that is also shown in this movie. We live in a superficial world with superficial thoughts and people can't seem to just get the point of deep thought. I would personally recommend this to anyone and well if they don't like it. They just don't. Seems to me they are all upset over having their expectations broken rather than enjoying the true masterpiece of art that it was.

As someone mentally challenged, the movies makes even more sense. They found a brilliant way to show his delusions and hallucinations. That was through music and casting Gaga. Phoenix and Gaga are amazing together and I suggest everyone watches this with an open mind!

Joaquin and Gaga were amazing. Both showedperfect acting in this sequel and have proven to be the right picks, it's a match made in heaven.

While a lot of people do not like the musical aspect (which i truly can understand, looking at the kind of movie the first part was), i think it really shows the 'folie a deux'. Furthermore, the negative reactions kind of prove the point in the movie: people only care when there is spectacle, being the joker, and do not care about the humanbeing and his mental state, arthur, himself. I think Todd managed to set up a movie in which exactly the same happens as in real life, which is kind of sad but very strong as well.

I really enjoyed this movie. Like i enjoyed first groundbreaking film. Do you know why? Because it was just a continuation of the first movie. Down-to-earth, sincere, which makes you feel in the place of the main character. And a musical! A musical that gives more meaning to words that reflects the natural behavior of every human being. After all, as they say: when you are extremely happy, you even want to sing, and when you are unhappy, you want to express this emotion in every possible way. I will eagerly wait for the 3rd and further parts of the film, because I think this is just the beginning of a great epic that has captured the hearts of the audience with its down-to-earth characters.

When I became aware of the bad reviews for Joker: Folie à Deux I did not bother to read them. I know that when it comes to reviews I tend to hate the movies that get glowing reviews, for example - Late Night With the Devil (an absolute waste of time) I don't need to be spoonfed films, I can use my imagination, and even though I do have ADD, I don't need films to punch me in the face continually. Joaquin Phoenix reprises his role as Arthur Fleck (Joker) with undeniable striking talent and screen presence, with Lady Gaga as Lee Quinzel shining just as brightly, and forever more reigning as Harley Quinn. Her ability to embrace mental illness all-encompassing was mesmerizing, from the look in her eyes to the pallor of her skin, to the condition of her hair. Her insane fan Girling for the Joker was demented and scary. Witnessing Arthur Fleck struggle with the need to feel wanted and be true to himself was watching him on his course of self-destruction. Knowing his gut was telling him, warning him, but he just had to keep touching the open flame. The use of the musical scenes to denote his delusions was brilliant. All Arthur aspired to be was a performer, it only seemed fitting that his delusions be illustrated that way. The original Joker film, I found had almost a musical undertone to it. No there was no bursting into songs, but it was expressed in Arthur's movements, that at times were like Expressive dance. If you truly loved the first film, I can not see why you do not love this film just as much. Even the ending was sheer perfection, I don't want to put any spoilers in here. But if you haven't seen the film, make sure you watch carefully and keep an eye on the background.

Joker: Folie à Deux does not deserve bad reviews, people need to open their eyes and use their brains more. Don't let the bad reviews stop you from seeing this film. I know I am definitely going back to the cinema to see it again. I truly hope that Phillips does not give up on the DC universe because of the haters.

Todd Phillips really takes things to a new level with this one. It's not just a follow-up to Joker; it's an evolution. Joaquin Phoenix returns with an even more disturbing portrayal of the Joker, fully embracing his descent into madness. But what really stands out is the addition of Lady Gaga as Harley Quinn. Her performance is captivating, adding a dynamic that feels both dangerous and tender.

The musical numbers are unexpected, but they work, giving a surreal edge to the film. The cinematography is also stunning, with Gotham looking darker and more alive than ever. Phillips manages to blend chaos with beauty, crafting a psychological thriller that's also a tragic love story. It's not just a comic book movie anymore-it's something deeper.

Not going to do a long review as there are many good ones I agreed with listed by those who enjoyed it. I found the movie entertaining and beautiful visuals, great musical pieces and I'm not a huge fan of musicals.

The story for me was a full circle movie for Arthur from being a beat up clown in an alley to the end shot. Loved how Arthur's singing was not great in the gritty scenes but were god in his fantasies. Lee was a great character and kinda wish she was in it more.

I loved the first Joker and this was a good continuation of the story to me. Didn't care for the split personality defense, I think a mental health person snapped would have been better but split personality followed the me and my shadow theme.

This is Arthur Fleck's world and we are living in it. Wonderful character study. The movie brought tears to my eyes multiple times, there is immense emotional depth to it. Love is portrayed beautifully as well as what having mental health issues is actually like: not a fancy story, just sad and many times, hopeless.

The musical moments add to it, they are it. It is not annoying as I usually find it with traditional musicals.

This is also not your traditional, commercial Joker. The Joker here is laid bare for the world to see his true nature. The movie is about one person's demons and having to face the consequences of his own actions. And making a choice. Truth or Lie.

It is rare that life offers us the necessary elements to fulfil our desired narrative. While in the first movie, life was quite tolerant of Arthur's narrative, in the last one, the story gets real, and life senseless (or at least not with the sense we hope to give it).

The soundtrack is still haunting my thoughts as I write this review.

The word disappointment probably appears in more reviews here than the words Joker or Harlequin. But this film was not a disappointment to me. Why not? I suspect mostly because I went to see it knowing full well it was a 'jukebox musical'.

Strangely enough, I watched the first Joker film on a whim, expecting a DC superhero (anti-hero) film. I left the cinema agape, blown away by the power of the film and the strength of the performances.

I went into this cinema this time having read the reviews and the seeming disbelief that the hard-hitting grit of the first film had been followed up with a musical.

I must say, though, that I left the cinema after watching the second Joker film equally impressed by the performances, and equally impressed by a film that once again breaks convention.

It's tough pill to swallow, because it's far away at what people want from The Joker. It's far away from the original movie, but it's way better than original. In first movie we see his actions in other hand in this one we see his inner though, his persona , his illness which is shown through music and songs. Somewhat dark lyric, helplessness in his voice. There's almost zero action outside, but inside it's different. Extraordinary casting and play. Unbelievable cinematography it's beautiful and dark, raw at the same time. Extraordinary movie for people who abstracts from original one. Must see but forget first movie and open your mind.

It was such a tragic story of a mentally challenged, abused person. And it was portrayed to a perfection by Juaquin Pheonix. I agreed songs can be trimmed but nonetheless it was a perfect.

My only issue is with the in some moments abrupt initiation of songs when there was a serious moment and i wanted to get mote to it and suddenly song will start.

Lady GAGA hods on her own in this film and I hoped some scene should have been cut which explains her character more which was showed in film.

Going forward i hope James Gunn will continue the vision of Todd Philips for the Villans and their solo films.

The ambiguity of the first film takes a leap down La La Land with this follow up.
