Again, all of the conversations are mainly centred around standout lyrics from songs and musicals to cast the presumption and possibility that there's really no physical dialogue actually taking place. The vocal performances are fantastic but especially from the untrained, broken and vulnerable tones of Joaquin Phoenix. The sound design and score was again on top form, as were all of the arrangements. Whilst some sets were obviously designed to embrace the fantasy and fanciful style of classic and lavish musicals, there are occasions where it is the lighting which plays its role at transforming whatever the 'real world' set is into becoming a mindful grandiose stage. I think it will alienate a lot of the audience (there have been multiple and numerous groans from people every time another song begins), but thankfully I did get the majority of the reference points, so again, loved the performances.

I think I've invested myself into a potential backstory of the character enough to be able to tell this fictionalised version of fantasy and reality to just be happy to let the story unravel itself, whereas if you are presuming to take it all at face value then it will feel disjointed.

Go watch the movie as it will take you on a journey through pathologies and it will leave you with a weird and quirky feeling of "why am I feeling empathy towards a human being that is the image of turning the human being inside-out?"

Splendid acting from Phoenix and Gaga and incredible directing. Scenes roll out in a festival of allegories.

The music is just enough to push the point of a possible silver lining in the mad man's world, "even a crazy bird will sing" but not enough to turn it into a musical. The bad reviews for this movie come from people who went to see it with a marvel mindset, it was pretty clear from the first Joker that this is a mistake.

This is a masterpiece. Once again, I feel that viewers' opinions are completely unreliable. While it encapsulates past classics like Dancer in the Dark and Chicago within itself, it also destroys the image of the Joker from the first movie. (In my opinion, it's akin to the liberation in Thus Spoke Zarathustra.) This film takes the next step toward redefining the 'villain' figure. While there are many negative opinions, it's clearly stated right from the opening sequence, isn't it? However, it's frustrating to think that so few people in the world can grasp such complex characters anymore. Throw away your phone, you idiot. Pay attention to people. Idiot!

This was a deep dive to humans cruelty and suffer. Music was the small get away from it. Every time, you feel uncomfortable, sad or happy or any kind of strong feeling, movie has reachead it's goal. All sugarcoated movies has their place but that's not all. As allways Joaquin made it. Lady Gaga was playing her part well as a very twisted woman. Enough unexpected turns. The more time goes by, the more it's getting richer in many ways. No for fun, but for hope in any ways. I presume, their is also a cultural gap between us here, in nordic countries. Us known as "nordic noir" movies and series. Handling dark and long winters gives us glomy mindset? Watch it at least twice!

Just watched "JOKER: FOLIE À DEUX".

The bad reviews online scared me but it actually became the reason why I enjoyed the film twice better.

I also love the way they chose music for this movie. All the songs perfectly describe the story and Gaga's vocals nailed them.

Her performance in this movie proves that she's a professional actress. Without her, trust me, none of these would be possible.

And don't even get me started on Joaquin Phoenix, y'all already know who he is.

The finale of this movie is something I'll need so much time to process. I was just so surprised by the end.

This movie is so deep with such a deep meaning behind it. Definitely a must-watch.

All Arthur wanted to do was hear the song, but he was dragged away before he could find his light.

This is not a movie for the masses, not a spectacle for the sheep. This is cinema for those who love art and life.

The madness of two, is not only the inclusion of another chaotic persona, but the repercussions of this second film. This is not a sequel. This is not a musical. It is a coda for a beautiful character whose only means of self expression were defiled by those who naively felt a need to bask in the spectacle of his shadow.

A harsh commentary on sensationalism, the purpose of art, and the means in which all things without a voice are culled by misunderstanding and ignorance.

A billion dollars made this, YOU wanted this. But sadly YOU don't know what to do with it. Stop biting the hand that feeds you, you'll starve.

We saw this today at Odeon luxe.

I don't go by reviews as opinion is subjective. This was a superb film. The character development and storytelling were sublime.

I loved how these two mentally disordered people expressed themselves through music and singing. It all fitted together like a jigsaw.

The acting from Joakim from phenomenal and Gaga was brilliant too. Joakim will surely get an Oscar for this.

I'm a mental health nurse of 27 years so perhaps I could relate to the characters better than someone who doesn't have this experience but I found it incredibly sad and the scene where the Joker was laid naked on his front by the Guards was particularly harrowing bearing in mind the Joker's previous abuse.

The ending was also desperately sad but I'm sure the story will not end there.

I would go so far as to say that the whole production is a work of genius and it was well worth our time and money.

Got the luxury to go see this with my wife. Have to admit that I was initially a bit offset by all the negative press, but that rinsed off already in the starting minutes of the flick.

There are multiple stories factored in. The focus on the psychological conflict inside Arthur is still heavily in there (like in the first part) and the emotional and at times raunchy musical bits are a pure joy to follow. I really applaud that the music actually allows to dig deeper into the character mindsets, and by doing so it gives way more dimension and depth than pure storytelling could ever do. Bravo.

On top of the above, the dark romance between Joker and Harley is vividly brought to life. Better than ever before. Regardless of what comes after the movie events, this was truly powerfully done.

After seeing the movie and digesting it all, you can re-piece the experience anew to get it all to yet another level by connecting it all to the Batman universe. Simply wow. Candy for the brain.

Hats off to the producing crew, Joaquin and Lady Gaga. Thank you for making this happen. Pure genious!

Funny funny, what to expect from a joker but to give a great not so expected joke... People anticipating on another glorification of violence sequel, are served with a romantic musical. With great performances of joaquin and gaga. And the storyline goes on from joker 1 with lots of familiar faces and incidents and directed in a interestingly smart way. Love this movie, thank you for daring to put something less expected in the universe of super heroes and so. This one is sure one to watch if you're truly interested in the heart and soul of joker instead of another all guns out blazing movie forgotten when leaving the cinema.

The psychological elements and themes were thoughtfully crafted in this fever dream. While the awkward star power casts away the shadowy charm of the original Joker it would be untrue to consider this a bad sequel. Instead, it poignantly reflects the narratives we construct in our own minds.

Joker 2 clears the poker table with an all-in bet, confronting cycles of trauma and fear head-on. The sequel serves as a necessary wrap-up to the important messages introduced in the first film, which profoundly shook our zeitgeist. In a world where we continuously witness the effects of fear, judgment, and victimhood, this film underscores the idea that these narratives can become mere bad stories we tell ourselves to escape the harshness of reality. Joker after Joker this film couldn't have come out at a more important time. Fear, judgement, victimhood, it's just a bad story people read to themselves so that we can fall asleep to life.

In conclusion, Joker 2 arrives at a pivotal moment, reinforcing its predecessor's impact while exploring the complexities of human experience.

*sigh* But yeah, some suburban nerd said, "Lets make a musical."

I absolutely loved it!

When I came out of the cinema after the first movie - I was dancing on the street like he did in the bathroom scene! I was absolutely mesmerized by him as a character and to this day Joker is one of my favourite movie.

After seeing this one I burst out into tears and not because it was that bad , it's because it was that sad and I was moved.

Absolutely heartbreaking story of a troubled man who's been abused and traumatised as a child...never really understood love and never really had a personality to develop...his escape is being the Joker! The Joker who doesn't care about consequences and only wants chaos!

In this movie the musical element is key. That is his only way of communication for love which he finally feels...the only hope he can escape to in his miserable life.

I feel that what the director did with the characters was very bold and thought provoking! It did surprise me and I'm a big "comic book Joker and Harley fan". I loved this movie for multiple reasons! It's a different take on the characters...but this is not about the Joker... it's about Arthur and I think that's the key! Another masterpiece!

Hot take: Joker: Folie à Deux is one of the greatest Comic Book Movie of all time, like genuinely, I don't think I've seen anything better and the only two movies that can compare is either Morbius or Madame Web. The people who say this movie is bad don't understand cinema or are pseudo intellectuals. If you can, I highly recommend you to watch this movie and let me know how it is - I would genuinely do anything to watch this movie for the first time again.

Continuing on, Joaquin Phoenix's and Lady Gaga's acting is mesmerizing, truly phenomenal and recordbreaking, I didn't have high hopes for this movie when I heard it was gonna be a musical but goddamn this movie is breathtaking.

The visuals and CGI is S tier like every DC movie, you can tell the directors and VFX team put a lot of heart and effort into making this movie and rating it any lower than a 9/10 is a disgrace to actual cinema fans who know masterpieces when they watch one.

Todd Phillips' original Joker 2019 wasn't that great, it was a D tier movie with overhyped acting and writing, but Joker: Folie à Deux fixes all of that with amazing writing, phenomenal acting, great visuals and cgi, and last but not least, an absurdly good sidecast and team.

Dexays overall review: 9.8/10

Sincerely, Dexays.

I loved everything about this movie. Every song had a meaning pertaining to him. It was soulful and beautiful. A look inside his tortured life. The music was spectacular The acting was astounding. 10/10. I think I will download the soundtrack. Gaga was so amazing and beautiful.

I am a bit older so the song choices were so wonderful to listen to.

I really enjoyed the court room antics.

I am so confused about the ratings not being high.

I do recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys something different. A breath of fresh air.

All in all I'm very happy I chose to goa nd see this movie Defiantly recommend.

Humanity is unpredictable. We desperately want to be allies of what's right while hiding our opinions when we favor that which is deemed wrong. Joker: Folie a Deux is being ridiculed by many people for a multitude of reasons. It's the first comic book movie to earn a D CinemaScore, it has a 33% rating on Rotten Tomatoes, 5.3/10 on IMDb, and 45% on Metacritic.

So, why did I enjoy this movie when seemingly no one else did?

Todd Phillips writes a beautifully complex story detailing the unbearable challenges of seeking acceptance and validation in a world of characters who are trying to do the same. What's the number one human desire? To feel important. Joaquin Phoenix shows us two descriptive versions of this character: one who puts on a face and showcases a fluffed confidence because of the validation/attention he receives (shadow version of Arthur Fleck), and one who's broken, lonely, and timid with vulnerability (real version of Arthur Fleck). This isn't a version of the Joker we've seen before, nor is Phillips trying to get to that point. Rather than focusing on the result of the Joker character as seen in performances from Heath Ledger, Jack Nicholson, and Mark Hamill, audiences are given layers of insight into how this particular character (or others around him) could eventually end up in a place of complete madness while maintaining a sense of honest identity. Hildur Guðnadóttir elevates the personality of this story with her deeply penetrative score alongside a masterful and practical visual compilation from Lawrence Sher. The musical element works because of its imperfection, but the more grand each production becomes, the farther away those moments feel from what the story is trying to say. This is a human story living within a superhero world, and though the flare of creating crimes or saving people from them feels absent, the inspiration for creating a villain has never felt more authentic (hence the concluding scene).

I loved every minute of the movie. A very powerful and moving story. It is very important to notice that people of Gotham don't really care about mental illness, they are only interested in the cult of JOKER, they only want to see and hear JOKER and so does the audience. At the moment when the film becomes more about Arthur than Joker, the audience makes a judgment that the film is bad. We have to understand that JOKER movie is not about being silly and frivolous and people go to the cinema expecting that. If you plan to see this movie, pay special attention to the cartoon that is shown at the beginning, it is very important for the plot.

I really loved the movie and think it was brilliant.

I will rewatch it next week!

Also, don't really understand the hatred for musicals.

I read the reviews on here, mostly bad, just before I went to the cinema and thought, oh well, if it's that bad it's just a movie.

I sat there expecting not to like it, but found myself drawn in, I started to understand why using music/signing was so important, it added an extra depth into the mind.

I think those who focussed on it being partly a musical didn't really understand the first movie. I think we have a long way to go before mental health is understood and looked upon by society.

Loved the filming, acting, not sure lady gaga was the best choice, but she wasn't that bad a choice either. Definitely something worth watching in the cinema.

Yes this is mainly a musical movie and a great one, the dramatic plot being a pretext but well conceived and acted. Joaquin Phoenix (the Joker) is a great actor and performs an excellent part in a complicated one. The plot is about his double personality as Arthur Fleck. In custody at Arkham State Hospital awaiting trial for the crimes he committed before and as the Joker, a great comedian who has lots of fans who even want that he becomes free. We will then follow his trial where he dismisses his lady lawyer and also simultaneously his love affair with Harleen "Lee" another patient at the Hospital. This has several dramatic events including a severe bomb explsion thet destroys thr court room and kills and injuries several people. This is an excellent movie including visual tchnique and acting perfrormance.

I actually enjoyed it. This was not your typical DC movie, however I do think people that are not open minded and in the world of fine arts will understanding the depth of what the director was trying to do. As an artist the psychological part in producing something different away from its norm IS always a challenge. Joker 2 did continue its story from part one and how he became vulnerable when he meets someone. I absolutely loved how all aspects of the fine arts was add to this movie. Not many will understand and that's ok, but this movie was not horrible as everyone is claiming it to be. Open your mind to something different. Story tell becomes dull at one point when it is repetitive.

I do not understand the overwhelming hate this movie has received, much of it seeming like bandwagon criticism. While I get that some viewers had different expectations, this film should not be crucified for taking a unique approach.

The standout aspect is the stunning cinematography. Every scene feels carefully constructed, from the shot composition to the transitions and camera angles - it is truly a visual masterpiece! Joaquin Phoenix, as expected, delivers a phenomenal performance, embodying the role perfectly. Lady Gaga, despite initial skepticism, turned out to be a refreshing surprise, bringing an unexpectedly fitting vibe to her character.

The narrative takes an unconventional route, pulling us into the Joker's chaotic mind and blurring the boundaries between fantasy and reality. This creates a dynamic, bold storytelling approach that contrasts euphoria with misery in a way that feels unique to the film.

That said, the musical elements, though fitting at times, occasionally felt excessive. Additionally, Harley Quinn's role left too many unresolved questions, coming across as unfinished. The portrayal of the attorney also puzzled me, as the character felt unnecessarily irritating and unlikable.

One of the film's strengths lies in how it humanizes the Joker, exploring his psychological vulnerabilities and blending them with reflections on mental health and identity. This gives the movie an additional layer of complexity.

In summary, this is a bold sequel that caught many by surprise. Despite the backlash, it is a high-quality film with exceptional cinematography and performances. For those who appreciate the art of cinema, I highly recommend it.

With all the negativity around it, I almost feel obliged to apologise for ....yes: loving it.

There are a few reasons why that is:

First of all: if Joker was a reminiscence to Taxi Driver, this one is highly inspired by "Dancer in the Dark". There are, in my opinion many similarities! So I get where Todd is coming from, when and why the musical scenes happen.

I love slow transition of Lee to Harley Quinn. The easy to miss first patterns on her stockings to her last outfit.

The Gary Puddle scene is incredible.

And the ending is the perfect transition ... it I keep it vague to not spoil it.

The acting is still great from Joaquin Phoenix & Lady Gaga.

The cinematography is superb.

Last but not least: I can highly relate to his mental state and think it's depicted authentic and believable.

Maybe in the future, people will look back at this movie just like on "The Crow" from 1994. Critics and viewers didn't like it back then, but it's fanbase grew over time to a cult classic.

You can disagree and I get where people are coming from.

But I dare to say: I love it.

And I am not sorry to say so.

Superb film with a great performance by Lady Gaga and nothing short of an Oscar winning performance by Joaquin Phoenix in a film which is probably not a superhero fan favorite, but which is brave and constantly surprises. The inclusion of songs works to perfection and is used intelligently and seamlessly throughout the film, and adds to its boldness. The film also works as a critique of the current toxic political climate, where lies and deception have become openly valid and accepted strategies. My biggest surprise concerning this brilliant film, though, has been how few people get it and must have left the cinema feeling let down by its intentional omission of any Batman or other superhero references.

Just an amazing film, with great writing, acting, directing, photography, audio etc. If you are allergic to songs in a film or expect some traditional action then save yourself the time and don't bother. Stop hate-bombing this film.

If you want a captivating, emotionally mature film (and wish I could say more but I hate spoilers) then go watch it!

I see so many people give it a 1 star rating because they thought they were going to watch the next Batman, I guess. To me this film perfectly explores the themes in the first movie and develops the main character. The portrayal of Harlequin fits well into the set universe.

Just came out of the theater, and I get why fans of the traditional Batman Universe Joker might not warm up to this version.

However, if you're open to a fresh take on the character, one that explores the dark, passionate, and redemptive aspects of the Joker-set to the backdrop of soulful blues-you're in for something special.

Joaquin Phoenix is nothing short of brilliant in his portrayal. You don't just watch him; you feel him embody the Joker's complex, tortured persona in a way that's deeply immersive.

That said, I estimate that maybe 10% of viewers will truly connect with and be captivated by "Joker: Folie à Deux".

For me, though, this film is both tragically beautiful and undeniably brilliant.

I think a lot of people badly misunderstand this movie. They expected a movie that was exactly the same as the first movie, but the protagonist is in a VASTLY different world.

This is the story of fantasy blending with reality. The conflict of the world at large disagreeing with a man's internal one. At the same time, a world begging for his fantasy to be reality to use him as a device of retribution. With a world hungry for the kind of justice he could create if only he would give in and embrace the dark world of his fantasy, of rage, of destruction.

The nature of this movie is indulgence. Indulging a mad man's vast incompetency. Of misguided people suffering in a dark world NEEDING his fantasy to come true. A world craving the destruction, hatred and death that would unleash.

Of his world being supported in fantasy and his experiencing of something that would have required him to stop being part of who he really was. For him to shun his humanity and embrace something darker.

This is not a fun movie. It is not one which is easy to watch or super enjoyable, the musical numbers are hollow and discordant, the expressions of love are false, misleading. The entire plot is the unraveling of something that never existed, a fantasy, living that fantasy and upon realizing its loss, losing everything except himself.

I can see why people hated the movie. I understand it. But this movie is in MANY ways an artistic masterpiece. Something so raw and unburdened by delivering something as expected that it does something really brave, terrible and difficult to watch.

I have watched this at the cinema on release date, I found the film depressing but the music added some light which it needed.

The film left me feeling exhausted as the plot of the film went in all directions, it was disjointed at times.

Overall it was a good film. I have seen the first film and I'm glad this film wasn't as dark.

I am a fan of lady gaga and her music but not her films.

I feel her range of acting skills isn't there, the characters she plays in most films seem like the same person.

I feel she is playing lady gaga in every film and I find it tiresome.

Gaga the musician is great but gaga the actor is not.

I'm a jaded movie buff who's watched too many movies. These days it's a challenge to find something engaging. The first Joker left me luke warm, but I loved this one. I feel like watched a different movie to the reviewers who called it boring. But I don't like superhero movies. They truly are boring and not what I understand as real cinema.

Folie à Deux is to me study in pain, brilliantly portrayed by Joaquin Phoenix. This is not a musical in the traditional sense. More a mockery of a Hollywood musical, as you expect from the Joker, no? Each song as performed by Phoenix is a howl of pain. This movie is dark and twisted, like the Joker is supposed.

Or do you prefer the pantomime Joker by Nicholson?

The Jocker mocks musicals, and courtroom dramas, and prison movie tropes, he mocks lawyers, and judges, and the Joker mocks his own fan boys that try to own him by "freeing" from the courtroom. That's exactly what we should expect the Joker to do, isn't it? Or did you think you were immune from his mockery? He's calling you a schmuck. Yes, you. That's what the Joker does - nobody is spared, right? In his eyes, we are all the joke.

In 2019, i watched Joker with a couple friends at the theater, had no idea what the general reception of the film was, didn't even know it was rated r, we just felt like going to the movies. While my friends and i kinda looked at each other during the movie it became obvious that they were more like, "wtf is this i thought this was gonna be a superhero movie" and i was like "is this allowed? I didn't know it was ok to release movies like this, but i love it." and now in 2024 i go to the theater and once again, this was NOT what i expected.

Unlike last time, i knew the general reception going into this, people are clearly not into it. But uknow what, i haven't been to the theater in a bit, might as well see what all the talk is about. And yea i see why so many people couldn't get on board with this, but turns out i was 100% the target audience.

If you wanna see the psychological deconstruction of a clown with a killing streak told through musical numbers and a thick cloud of cigarette smoke, than this is the movie for you. Bonus points for good songs, impentitent social commentary, and a three minute 2D animated segment. It's still not perfect but it was definitely better than i thought it would be, even before i saw all the negative reviews.

So I went in expecting it to be as bad as everyone seems to be claiming it to be, and left impressed.

Yes it's a musical and yes it's probably not what we expected it to be. But that doesn't mean it's not brilliant.

If you go into this wanting it all to be about joker and a backstory etc then your going to leave disappointed. It's Arthur's story, about how his mind has been shaped by his trauma. The musical elements fit perfectly in my opinion and I love how it reflects Arthur's fantasy.

I feel like the people leaving negative reviews must be marvel fans lol, and to those saying there was no story? The idea of joker is him having no back story! And this film isn't really about joker it's about Arthur!

Great film.

It's an artistic movie and not a marvel actions packed movie.

If youve grown up with actions figures, if you love the DC world, if you love the idea of Batman and joker in the real world and if you know " I'm just one bad day away from you"

Go watch it!

The movie is amazing and has an Easter egg too, if you're not blind that is, which seems to be the case with the world giving bad reviews.

I generally don't write reviews because apparently you gotta add 500 characters Only putting up the efforts because reviews made me question the decision of going to an Imax to watch the movie, but just walked out of the theatre and putting a review is the first thing I'm doing so that people who actually like movies and the DC world don't get dissuaded.

Good to get something really different second time around.

Saw it as a part 2 extension & insight into The Jokers personality PBA/PD disorder.

Complex, confusing, changing, chameleon, unconventional & off-centre.

Appreciate for many the film will disappoint. But for us psychologists & therapists its looking at the film from many different angles.

Whilst i often immerse into films & just flow & watch, for this its different. Its analysis, pattern hunting & seeing how to cope with narcissistic, childhood trauma.

It did drag in parts but life is not consistent box ticking. Ga Ga & Phoenix were great.

Loved it!

The film is profoundly deep in analyzing human nature and character.

It shows the whole spectrum of human emotions and different emotional needs.

It is enough to follow the main character, his emotions and the relationships he has with all the characters in the film, as well as the emotions of the masses who put his dysfunctionality on the throne, which he wants to renounce, but without it he is nothing again in the eyes of his crazy followers.

This is a psychological thriller where the action only serves to accompany the emotional twists. Starring Joaquin Phoenix deserves another Oscar. The film shows society and tendencies in detail, and that's the only thing we can dislike about this film, because it shows them as they are in all their ugliness.

Joker 1 was the destruction of Arthur for the birth of the Joker, as his soul played a voiceless instrumental within his mind for he has no one, no one to voice himself to.

The sequel starts with Arthur reclaimed as a beaten man with consequences from a shadow that has taken his face to commit chaos. Arthur accepting of his consequences, until he finds hope through love. Love that he will never realize is a toxicity that fuels this shadow that Arthur himself would much rather be without, for the shadow has Arthur's dreams but will take it in the ways that will burn all around them.

Joy & Gloom.

Despite hearing all of the overly critical reviews, I branched out and watched it anyway, with low expectations. As a fan of the first movie, this was not at all that, though still a wonderful viewing experience. If you were expecting something similar to the first movie, you'll be surprised by the different, more toned down and romantic vibes of the sequel. The violent aspect is done tastefully and the effects are decent, though some of the blood physics are slightly off. Overall, I found the pacing to be actually quite lovely and the music to be a beautiful addition to an already beautiful movie. Not to mention the excellent cinematography. Cast and crew did an amazing job on this one. 8/10 "No, Gaga!" -quote while watching film.

Lady gaga pleases audiences with her standout acting for this role as Lee! This movie is cohesive to the first one, but at the same time is refreshing and new. This new embodiment of Harley is real and raw to the point her craziness surpasses that of Arthur. Musical sequences may not be for everybody, but they are placed at points in the movie that truly help understand how Joker and Lee see the world through their perspective. Story itself does take a slow pace to fully take off, but when it does, you do get to experience the pain, sadness, happiness, and drama that is unveiled all within 2hrs of this movie. Surprise twists that were unexpected within this movie and it's worth a watch if you loved the first one!

Should a Director just go for what the audience is expecting? Or should a Director be creative, challenge and daring the audience?

I would go for the second one - although some might know - Cinema is an Art. Not mass production.

Joker Folie à Deux it's not a sequel, nor a Spin-off. It's a Masterpiece.

What were haters and critics waiting after Joker? This movie is not Joker II - is Joker Folie à Deux.

No doubt one of the best movies (ART) I've seen this year - I rated it 10/10.

Sorry haters & critics that just wanted a Joker II - I understand the disappointing - but thank you, Todd Phillips for the Folie à Deux, the best movie I've seen this year.

I loved Joker, and I loved Folie à Deux.

Joker: Folie à Deux dials up the tragedy to the max with a sequel that takes the kind of huge risks you're only allowed to do after you've made a billion dollars. It's the rare comic book film to actually commit to the genres it's hybridising as it's pretty much a 50/50 split between the musical and courtroom drama aspects. There's not a single comic book film like it, including its own predecessor, and there never will be.

Joaquin Phoenix is amazing as he avoids a retread of familiar ground by creating a larger divide between Arthur and Joker. Arthur remains so pitiful with his softly spoken voice and defeated nature whereas he's almost too confident once the makeup is on. However, there's a much greater turmoil here as Joker becomes more a performance to gain popularity than something he actually believes in, which visibly weighs on him.

Lady Gaga is great as a very unique version of Harley Quinn who's obsession with Joker is highly convincing. The romance that blooms between them is surprisingly sweet though not without it's darker elements and she's obviously got a phenomenal singing voice when it's needed. Even with a very small role Harry Lawtey brings the required self assured smarmy nature that defines this version of Harvey Dent.

Its generally too long but Todd Philips' direction makes up for it by being a lot more unique from the very start where it opens with a Looney Tunes style cartoon that basically sums up the central argument of the film. There's a great use of the IMAX aspect ratio to signal an incoming musical sequence and Lawrence Sher's cinematography is superb yet again thanks some astonishingly good long takes in particular.

The musical numbers are a more natural fit than they seem since music was already a vital part of the original. Some of them could've gone on for longer however they all nail the old Hollywood feel, allowing Arthur to escape into fantasy and they're sung in such an emotionally raw fashion. Because of those musical elements, Hildur Guðnadóttir's score takes a back seat for the most part whilst still being a beautifully bleak highlight.

With a bold idea to start with, the director Todd Philips managed to make everything just right. And it is not a musical.

It is consoling to see that there are people still genuinely passionate and ambitious about movie making, and there is still space for them in Hollywood.

This is what cinema should be, a piece of entertainment and an attempt of expression rather than just a series of bulk produced manufactured scenes of actions. It asks the audience to have an open mind, and to think and feel not knowing if it's their thing or not, which increasingly becomes an impossible request to fulfil.

It's very dark, claustrophobic, depressing , beautiful and a masterpiece, a pure art of a movie.

It's better than the first.

It establishes Arthur is no less powerful than Joker. The daringly original and brave movie is not about entertainment but as artistic as a great poetry or a painting. It challenges viewer's expectation and prediction almost all the time and in turn it presents something that's undeniably far more shocking, cruel and realistic . One can relate or identify to "I can't breathe" and other Police cruelty and the failure of the justice system. Beautifully crafted challenging your expectations every minute and instead giving something far more amazing.

If you didn't enjoy the Joker movie because of the musical aspect, grow up 😂 The new Joker movie was an unconventional and well made sequel that builds upon the first film's themes with a bold musical twists. It avoids the typical superhero movie formula by focusing deeply on Arthur Fleck through a psychological thriller. The decision to include musical sequences, where the music itself reflects Arthur's mental instability and relationship with Lee, adds a unique layer to the story. These moments give insight into his psyche, amplifying the narrative with songs compare reality and delusion, effectively mirroring his fractured state of mind. This musical element not only complements the Joker's identity as a performer (literally a singing clown) but also emphasises the emotional intensity of his journey.

Although some negative reviews focus on the film's departure from traditional superhero movie expectations in DC and Marvel, the unique approach of the movie allows for a more profound exploration of the characters challenges, soul, and transformation. Joaquin and Lady Gaga were perfect for those roles and truly brought the magic to life!

Overall, the movie's use of music and the psychological interplay between characters set it apart, making it an amazing watch for those open to a deeper, more soulful interpretation of the iconic character!

I don't why this film is getting so much hate! I think people going into it expecting a continuation of the first film or another Batman-esque Gotham villain film or some Marvel type film will be very disappointed. If you go into this abandoning all that and expecting a highly stylized, visionary look into the mental state of Arthur Fleck and mental illness and dealing with a disturbed world explored through amazing dance and musical numbers with the fabulous Lady Gaga as his counterpart- you'll love it. It's not the usual Joker film but I'm glad. I hate when sequels regurgitate their successful predecessor, copying all the parts that made it a box office hit; I don't usually agree with the term "brave" for cinema or music because I think brilliance is brilliance, not brave but Folie a Deux is brave and daring and Phillips takes Gotham to a new level. It is truly original in its use of music and dance whilst exploring Arthur Fleck's story and disturbed nature. I've never seen mental problems and state of mind so connected with music and song in a film. From the first number up until the last- you can tell exactly how his character is feeling just by type of song or dance and very subtle expressions or movement. And it's not cringe at all!

Him and Gaga have great chemistry and as always his acting is superb. He carries real empathy and heart within the character, as well as depravity. Gaga fits into his world perfect and her voice is dazzlingly. They're both great. I want more. Donald Gleeson as the prison guard was great too, he's always good.

Give it a few years when people have gotten over the shock of singing in a Joker film and it'll be a cult film. I've been listening to the Gaga album on repeat since. I hope it gains the credibility it deserves. Truly art. A real win for everyone involved. I hope they're not discouraged from the reviews. And please go see it.

One side complains how superhero movies have lost solid character pieces for the sake of CGI fight scenes.

Another side has trouble handling movies such as this one.

I wish there didn't have to be such a wide alienation from clever writing. I wish we could have more pieces like this, which are at least trying to convey something thought provoking.

Because truthfully, we love superhero stories when the characters are the most interesting thing. We love to see Batman be Bruce Wayne. We love to know how Joker got to be the way he did, as much as the hero.

This movie deserves more love than it is receiving. Thank you for trying to give us smart films, at least smarter than bizarre CGI alien zones, with CGI action figure battles, sandwiched between mind numbing exposition.

Thank you for trying. If you stay consistent, and keep giving it your all, return it to a thoughtful art piece, then perhaps the superhero genre will be something worth saving.

I really hope this is the mark of some clever story telling. Comics have always been art first, and appealing to children second.

Return to the art, and let the mature kids grow with time.

This movie and the music are beautiful and the acting is Oscar worthy. I would watch it again. It's about mental illness and trauma. The joker is a victim of abuse and society wants to keep him boxed as joker and a villain to give themselves validity. When joker decides to be Arthur Fleck, and become in touch with reality, they turned against him.

It's very deep and elucidates and unpacks the imaginary world of dissociation and mental escape.

I came out of the theatre almost in tears. I was amazed how good this movie was. I don't understand the negative reviews.

Wow 👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼👏🏼 Well done.

It was the perfect conclusion to the heartbreaking tale of Arthur Fleck, a man slowly shattered by the cruel indifference of society. He was never destined to become the Joker, and that's exactly what makes his story so powerful. It's a raw, emotional journey that leaves the audience reflecting on the thin line between despair and madness.

This sequel serves as a bold, daring closing chapter, one that transcends comic book origins and tells a story of humanity lost, and ultimately, of a man who never truly became a villain.

Each scene was a gift the audience, revealing the depths of Arthur's struggle and showcasing the beauty and pain of his descent. These artistic choices elevate the narrative, making it not just a sequel but a profound exploration of a troubled soul, leaving viewers with a lasting impression that lingers long after. I'm sure everyone will learn to love it with time, as it happen with the first movie. Thank you for this remarkable sequel and powerful end to his story!!!

Oh my goodness, this film is absolutely fantastic. Sad, tragic, painful and beautiful. The acting was amazing. I absolutely loved it. I think actually, it might even be better than the first film.

I don't understand why people are hating on it. I can only assume they either didn't understand the first film or they don't understand mental illness.

As someone who sings (yes, outloud) and dances when I'm out on my walks. As someone who has always felt an outsider. As someone who seeks comfort and safety in a fantasy world. As someone who has spent time in a psychiatric institution. As someone who has had suicidal tendencies. As someone who has a mental illness which some people try to play down ("well, aren't we all a little autistic?". No, Karen. We're not.) - and yes, that scene in the courtroom where his mental illness is being discounted hurt a lot and made me very angry). As someone who seeks justice and fairplay. And as someone who just tries to do good in a world which is bad, this film hit me hard and I found it incredibly emotional. Chapeau, Todd Phillips. Your film is art. I thank you from the bottom of my heart.

The movie has a shocking impact that makes you contemplate. The scenes are disjointed and that is the bolstering effect to the shocking impact. By being disjointed and chaotic, the movie forces you to profoundly pierce each scenes and comprehensively knit the scenes together. The sound effects and transition between music and speaking is so smooth and balanced that keep you on the edge of your seat the entire time to figure out the meaning of each scene. The occasional music jumping in brings out some deeper thinking about the themes of the scenes with the music in it. Clearly disjointing the scenes also helps you focus on each scene more without mixing the scenes up making it too much for your mind to handle. For instance, the scenes being disjointed have expressed more deeply the dynamic behavior and relationship between the characters, including between Joker and Harley. The character development and change are more clearly seen by disjointing the scenes.

The movie is chaotic, and being narratively cohesive will counter the shocking effect of the movie. Being cohesive will make the narration feel forced and make you not diving into each scene deeper. In the end, you are shocked about the chaos the movie brings and will think deeply about everything you just watched. After the ending, the movie will produce lasting thoughts on you.

People must understand the fact that a sociopath and psychopath personalities. You can't compare the dark knight's joker with this. Joaquin Phoenix perfectly shows a sick crime mastermind brain's inside. With its cinematography, cast and the musics this film deserves to be on the one of the top list. Therefore, all of these facts resembles to a point that this film is revoloutianary for all cinema and superhero films history. To feel the music and the sfx better you should watch this on cinema. The development of the character joker is nearly perfect. I believe that everyone can find a piece of his/herself in this film.

"Joker 2" stands out as a masterpiece of 2024 cinema, combining exceptional performances and stunning cinematography that elevate the narrative to new heights. Joaquin Phoenix's performance is, once again, breathtaking, bringing an emotional depth that captures the complexity of the character. He transforms not only physically, but also psychologically, conveying the Joker's anguish and vulnerability in a visceral way. The chemistry between Phoenix and Gaga, whose equally impressive performance enriches the narrative, brings a new dimension to the plot. Together, they create a fascinating dynamic, exploring themes of love and insanity that leave the audience reflecting on the nature of the human being. Furthermore, the cinematography in the film is a work of art in itself. The lighting choices and visual composition create a unique atmosphere that intensifies each scene. The dark, contrasting color palette reflects the characters' mental state, while innovative camera angles contribute to the audience's immersion in the story. The aesthetics not only complement the narrative but elevate it, making it a memorable visual experience. These elements, combined with visionary direction and an impactful soundtrack, solidify "Joker: Delirium for Two" as one of the best films of the year. It is a work that not only entertains, but also provokes deep reflection on the human condition. Given this, his nomination for several Oscars is more than deserved; is a celebration of a film that rewrites the rules of the genre and leaves an indelible mark on the history of cinema.

This movie knows what it is. This movie knows how to get its audience where it wants them. How the masses can grip onto the first movie and act like there's some great disconnect between the two is beyond me. This sequel is a perfect counterpart to its original, being opposite in certain ways and paralleled in others. It's bold, it's real, it's surprising. Also, this is the best live Harley Quinn we've had, so for what that's worth.

The music doesn't jar, it fits where it's put, and it's well done. The singing doesn't distract or feel squished, and it doesn't take away from the performances. It's a slower burn, for sure, but it's less indulgent and more painful than the first movie.

Arthur knows how to make his impressions and how unique the film really is. From what I have heard from others which came from Google review audiences was a bad idea and atrocious. From after seeing it today, Joker: Folie à Deux is a phenominal masterpiece. The performances, especially from Joaquin Phoenix, are nothing short of spectacular-once again proving his incredible talent. The writing is sharp, the production is top-notch, and it all comes together as a powerful piece of art. For those who criticize this film for not adhering strictly to the original comics, it's time to expand your perspective. This is more than a comic book adaptation; it's an exploration of emotions, psyche, and the human condition. It's not just about violence or mental illness-it's about making us feel deeply. This movie transcends the typical boundaries of superhero storytelling and offers something raw and real. Lady Gaga is truly still the musician as she represents. The musical number from a DC R-Rated film was definitely amazing idea. The opening scene when opens up like those early 20th century cartoons that theme definitely brings back childhood memories. I myself use to watch these cartoons but that theme in the opening was something I adore. This maybe one of my top tier films of this year along side with FURIOSA, GRAVE TORTURE, WINNIE THE POOH BLOOD AND HONEY 2, OUT OF DARKNESS, ARCADIAN and THE PEASANTS. Remarkable film and definitely be purchasing it on VOD when it comes out.

Despite the negative reviews, I really liked the movie. Joaquin Phoenix's performance, as always, is on top, and Lady Gaga pleased me with her version of Harley Quinn. The technical performance of the movie is to my credit. The musical numbers fully demonstrate the inner world of Arthur Fleck. Many viewers will find the movie long and boring, as the main events take place in two locations. But if you don't take into account the sluggish pacing, the movie doesn't deserve such negative reviews. Overall, I enjoyed the movie and would love to see a third part, although it probably won't happen, but it would be interesting to see a Batman from this universe.

First of all I will begin with the fact that most people hate that movie just because it turned out to be a musical. When the first joker movie was released they said that the next one they will make will be a musical so you shouldn't complain about that. Second of all a lot of people are upset of the fact that joker revealed that there is no real joker, if you watched the movie carefuly you could see that joker had his ''breaking point'' somewhere which I am not planning to spoil for those that haven't quite understood yet.

In my perspective i believe the movie was set up nicely and all of the scenes were full of meaning. To sum up, the movie was a great choice, obviously you CANNOT compare it to the first joker movie but I totally recommend it.

I never take time to write a review but this time I have to. It's singlehandedly on of the best movies I've seen in, well, forever. I was so excited and blown away that I would've bought tickets for another viewing right after I left the cinema.

For the people who are doubting to see this one, if you like multi-layered dark, psychological, sad, heartfelt, funny, emotionally engaging movies, GO AND SEE IT! I'm actually curious about this director's other films now, but these two Joker movies have to be his best performances ever.

I'm having a hard time remembering when I last had this reaction to a movie and that would have to be Django Unchained or Inglourious Basterds. I loved Taxi Driver, but I score Joker 2 way above it, like miles above.

The musical elements were absolutely not tiring or tedious but very fitting and blew me awaymultiple times. I was in awe of Joaquin's performance and although I was hesitant about the casting of Gaga, she complemented him to the T. The critics who stated that Todd didn't take advantage of the acting talent of Gaga didn't see what I saw obviously, because I was super impressed and she moved me many times.

Soooo much better than I could have expected and I will remember this one for EVER.

Even if you think the insanity of a musical is fully appreciated in a movie about the criminally insane, is one of the bad jokes, this picture is one of the good ones nevertheless. The flickering balloon of the Joker is allowed to bursts on prime time, in a world that is as caring as a ruthless gothic society can be. The music, the psychological roots, even the camera angles pay tribute to the clown's golden age.

And although he lets everybody down in the end, not more than the social conditions which bring him doom. This seems to be the narrators' way of showing how much they care, their tribute. It is an act true to the psychological architype he represents. It also is an honest assessment of the Joker as an allegory for the chaotic forces bordering to a crazy carnival of change. It kills that false promise. The Joker as a successful political leader; or insane criminals as a force of coherent change, would have amounted to a true betrayal.

This is a movie which can only be underrated in societies which prefer cheesy dick jokes over Bill Hicks. 8/10 (minus 1 because I hate musicals).

This movie was fun to watch, I enjoy it. I went in knowing it was going to be dark and gritty. Also Enjoy that it was somewhat a musical. I feel Joaquin Phoenix and lady Gaga did a good job. I also feel this is a movie you have to be open minded to see. If you know the joker and Harley quin character from the batman show and d.c batman comics , and other batman movies, then don't expect this to be those exact characters. This is a standalone sequel to the Joker movie and it's did bring alot of Joy, laughter, psychological fear, and alot of thrill. Please don't miss out on watching this movie just cause there's a expectation of what this movie should and shouldn't be.

This movie deserves so much respect and admiration. It really touched at my heart strings, I felt every little emotion from Joaquin as if it were my own.

Honestly, you have to know what it is like to be abused, forced to keep on smiling, to understand what his character is always trying to convey.

For me, the movie solely rests on phoenix delivering the performance of a lifetime.

Most people will give an outright bad review to this movie, only because they haven't developed an understanding of their own emotions, or haven't really been faced with challenges of this kind. It deeply moved me, I have been plagued with mental disorders when I was in my 20s and it tugged at me and reminded me of that pain so very much.

I'm thankful that there are still movie directors who want to relay raw emotion instead of just put out a violent, action movie.

I hope that other directors and script writers are not let down because their effort is recognised by some if not many and that's what they should be aiming at, staying true to their vision and not conforming to mass audiences.

It was a great and profound watch for me.

Let's be honest. Most of you aren't pissed about the fact that this is a musical. You're pissed because the director showed your fanboy villain to be a figment of the very imaginations he was meant to inspire.

Todd clearly hated the fact that a bunch of incels thought Joker was their Talisman. So instead of running away - he made a sequel to screw em. Fair play I say.

In creating this follow up the director has made a genius move. He's both stayed true to the first film - but shine a new light on the hero worship given and shown the incel fanboys that being a loner, cynic and hating the world isn't power. It's desperation. Open your windows and minds. There's a world of human love out there.

The moment I heard about the casting and the musical stuff, this is exactly what I had in mind. Was it preferable? No. Did it play good? Yes I guess. But I would've preferred a movie like the first one, more organized and balanced.

This one is still an incredibly amazing installment tho, just not the way I'd pictured after seeing the first one. No need to mention Phoenix' commitment into this. It just blew my mind.

Some scenes were just so obnoxious to see and hard to bear. Some of them were just not easy to conceive all at once. So this one definitely requires multiple watches which I like.

The film is just like the Joker's mind as I describe it. You don't just get it. You don't know what's real or not. You need to put things in places but sometimes you just end up being confused and lost.

As a matter of fact, I loved it. Thank you Phillips.

I really wanted to watch the film. It really bothers me that the world is tearing him apart so much and that well-known critics are also getting involved.

The first part is great and if you look at this second part, everything is actually consistent for me if you take the trouble to look closely. Even the music... I can certainly imagine that it doesn't suit the taste of other action comic admirers. The film is not pure entertainment, it is actually more something to think about.

I had to form my own opinion. And I can only recommend this to everyone.

Finally: The roles are perfectly cast. Great achievements! Thank you for this cinema experience!

A 10 from me!!!!

I get it, it's an musician, people don't really line the idea of that. But the music has so much stories in it. This movie has a lot och impressions and meanings that people don't understand and respect. So underrated. Also love lady Gaga!! Her vocals are so powerful and her acting is amazing, the acting in the movie was totally amazing and deserves more attention, I don't get the hate. I have seen the news not liking the movie because it was "meaningless" but I totally do not agree. I saw this movie with my dad in the cinema and we both walked oit of the cinema and loved it!! I hope it get better later!

What an incredible follow up to the original Joker! This time you see things from the eyes of the titular character and are a part of the madness instead of just a witness to it! I was concerned Lady Gaga would be too serious to plat Harley Quinn, but boy was I wrong! This is how to make a sequel. Making this a musicial really sets the tone of what it's like in Joker's mind. Not to spoil too much, but it shows how Joker and Harley escape with each other to ignore the real consequences of theirs actions and just revel in what they see as the fun part. My favorite Joker will always be Mark Hamil, but now Phoenix is a very close second.

Joaquin as masterful as in the previous movie, Gaga in her best role yet. Emotional and vulnerable which makes it complex, this movie won't be for everyone which is totally okay. Sometimes it's totally okay to be in the minority about things, especially if it's the right one. ✌🏻 It's totally fine to say that someone doesn't like the direction the second part took, but it's a crime to say that Joaquin and Gaga are bad in it and that it didn't follow the tone of the first part. The movie is called Folie à Deux and that's exactly what we got, and it is quite excessive to call it a musical when it is not in that classical form. The communication of the characters through songs only increased the dynamics and drama of the film and helped us understand their inner worlds a little bit better (which was actually a real enigma to us in the first part of the movie).

That Joker : Folie A Deux exists at all is a bit of an oddity given 2019 smash hit Joker was always meant to be a stand alone film. That it exists in this form; a song filled courtroom romance that can pretty much be classified as an anti sequel, is nothing short of extraordinary. I'm sure that when star Joaquin Phoenix decided he wanted another go around as troubled loner Arthur Fleck the money men at Warner Bros. Were rubbing their hands but hats off to director Todd Phillips for getting reportedly close to $200 million out of them for this insane vision of a follow up.

Picking up four years after the events of Joker, the Arthur we first see has been beaten down by his years of incarceration. He barely communicates and Brendan Gleeson's guard laments the fact he no longer amuses him and his colleagues with jokes. A glimmer of life returns when an encounter with fellow inmate Lee Quinzel (Lady Gaga) leads to a blossoming romance. Starved of affection for his entire life, Arthur is instantly besotted while Lee seems far more interested in the antics and mystique of Arthur's Joker persona than the man himself. About a third of the way in, the film switches from prison romance to courtroom drama as Arthur's beleaguered attorney tries to help him avoid the death penalty by proving he has multiple personalities. Her task is made harder as the limelight of the trial and Quinzel's affections fire Arthur up and he becomes more interested in showboating than saving his skin.

Joker may have presented itself as unconventional but Folie A Deux makes that film look like a four quadrant summer tentpole blockbuster by comparison. The first film wore its Martin Scorsese influence plainly (and why not, if you're making an angry white guy movie you may as well crib from the best) but the influences here are far more diverse. Obviously there are One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Next vibes (British institution classic Scum too) but there is also Francis Ford Coppola flop One From the Heart and old French classic The Umbrellas of Cherbourg. If its predecessor was a funhouse mirror reflection of a comic book movie, this film is the reflection of that original reflection, any DNA of a DC world unrecognisable.

And there are songs, lots of songs. Phillips has said he was reluctant to call the movie a musical because the idea of a musical is that you leave the cinema happy and you won't be smiling after this. He's not wrong (more on that later) but there's another reason that moniker doesn't quite fit, the songs don't advance the narrative. A tune's function here is a trip to fantasy land to explore a characters state of mind, not a line of communication between writer and audience. The visuals and performances during the songs are pretty great. Phoenix proved in 2005's Walk the Line that he can sing but what he does this time is completely different. Arthur is no songbird, raspy and off key he ambles his way through the songs but with such feeling it feels like hearing these classics for the first time. When Frank Sinatra sings about finally finding somebody you know he's never really had such difficulties, when Arthur sings it every word means everything to him. Lady Gaga might be even better. We know she can sing and she's perfectly melodic here, but not perfect. Just a little too slow, just a little off tune. Completely fitting for a character hiding the true extent of herself.

In terms of style, cinematography and emotion Folie A Deux is top notch. In terms of narrative through line it is lacking. The main story component is the courtroom drama but the film's unconventional nature means there is none of the cut and thrust that propels such scenes in other movies. We spend more time going over and recontextualising the events of the previous film than experiencing new ones. It's not a case of style over substance, it's just that the substance is in the observing rather the doing.

The other barrier to entry is that the film is pretty relentlessly grim. While Joker showed the world through Arthur's eyes, Folie A Deux shows the world's view of Arthur and it is not pleasant. Seen only as either a figure of hatred or ridicule, or a symbol of violent power, nobody gives a toss about the man behind the persona. He is, lest we forget, a multiple murderer so you can argue nobody should care but the system that ignored him first time round now takes great delight in punching him in the face. I'm sure this isn't the direction people who revelled in the previous films violent third act wanted Arthur's story to go but it feels like a natural progression for such a character. The film makers seem fully aware of the response their movie will get from certain sections of the fanbase and have made that a major part of the narrative.

Whether you love it or hate it (they are likely to be the only two reactions), the talent behind Joker: Folie A Deux cannot be denied and it stands as a triumph of creative ambition over bean counting. It will bemuse and infuriate plenty of the original movies fans and likely burn a hole in the pocket of Warner Brothers but will live in the memory and conversation long after a traditional sequel would have been forgotten.

8 cartoon shadows out of 10 clowns.

Before whilst reading all the negative reviews but loving the first film I decided I was just going to go and make up my own mind!

After: I'm so glad I did , I honestly totally enjoyed this...... and anyone who didn't, didn't get it fully..... wasn't bored for one minute..... There was so many hidden Easter eggs within the film and laid the foundations for another dark universe within the whole Batman theology..... I think Phillips deserves an Oscar for the film and it is a beautiful compliment to the first film whilst also maintaining its own as a totally valid sequel.....

Soundtrack was awesome. Gaga was great.

Honestly 9/10...... I thought it was brilliant, and I'm a hard-core Batman fan

#JokerFolieaDeux.

A very intriguing and at times disturbing storyline, the film truly is by definition 'Folie a Deux', it prompts you to think more about the origin of the Joker and what happened to make him the way he is, and that 'Lee' Lady Gaga's character is the perfect companion for the Joker, she creates the balance even if it is within the madness. Absolutely worth going to see! Lady Gaga's performance is a stand out in the film, she could perhaps have been utilised more in it if I was to try to find a criticism, her transition from the music industry to film is one like I've never seen before, she seems to 'live and breathe' as the character she plays in the films she's in which makes you completely forget that it's 'Lady Gaga' she melts into the role.

Forget about the DC story or the script. The acting in the movie is genius. Joaquin takes you on A ride and shows you exactly what the Joker is really thinking. And how insane the Joker is. Joaquin Phoenix is one of the best actors of our time. And the movie needs to be commended for that reason alone. Lady Gaga as Harley Quin is perfect for the role. Her music and singing fits well into the world of the Joker. Harley also has her own fantasy of life and wants to live in it. Not the real world of where she comes from. Together they both take into the insane but beautiful mind of the Joker. I loved this movie and thought it was very entertaining.

People watched this film with pre-concieved expectations, for the joker to descend into complete chaos and mischief.....but people weren't ready to accept Arthur Fleck as a remorseful human being. Harlay Quinn is almost a metaphor for the negative reaction this film is getting and represents that audience/negativity.

I feel it's a lazy description of this film to call it a musical, yes there's plenty of music but I think it's truly reflective of their mental states and whether they are delusions or not.

This is the destruction of the Joker alter ego Arthur had and the rise of Harlay Quinn.....there's more to her character and I feel we're just scratching the surface with her.

Amazing Joaquín Phoenix a pleasure to see him perform on this beautiful psycho thriller-drama. Intense feelings through out the movie. Perfection. Sad to see ppl who loves Hero nonsense movies give bad critics to such a wonderful production. As my title states if film's name was Arthur Flek would have 9/10+ stars. Congrats to Gaga too, not an actor but she did fine, a humble and decent person can feel this movie and gets into the role so well. They matched so well on this. Finally, good job to all who contributed to this film , really well lit amazing quality, depth on every level sound , effects, actors! A pleasure to watch!

When I saw the trailer for this movie, I immediately went and watched the first joker movie. Within minutes I knew the second movie was going to be phenomenal. First, Lady Gaga is always a good choice. Second, if Lady Gaga is in the movie she's going to sing. Thirdly, the music enhances the movie. Not only is it fantastic music, but it helps to tell the story, and it helps to show each character's frame of mind, and how they were connected, even if in reality they never met. They were both delusional. They lived in a state of madness. That's the point. I'm not sure why this movie resonated so hard with me, but it did. It's entirely possible that the brilliance of using all of the incarnations of the character, joker, that we have been exposed to since his inception, Gives us a full picture of exactly how the character processed information inside of his own brain. If you're one of the people that does not understand this movie, I pity you. I wonder if it was just too nuanced for the average person. I wonder if it just went over peoples heads, the use of all of the symbolism. I hope it didn't. I hope people go back and watch this movie a second time and realize that , the camera angles, the exact words that were spoken the songs that were utilized, and the timing in which those songs were played was perfection.

If you didn't like this film you are religious. What we are looking for is...logic. LOGIC over dogma. Logically enjoy the madness.

Was the film expertly produced, the acting outstanding, did time ease by, did it not entertain!

Sure they were quick to the singing in every scene. Balance could have been achieved with more drama, more character interactions and some cell wall head banging. A bit of explicit trauma before delving in to the dancy mind of the mad.

You can slate the visualization of the thoughts of the insanely fantastical, but that is unfair. This film in the arch of what may inspire The Joker to transpire, is substantive enough to stand a test of time.

Had the pleasure of seeing in BFI IMAX, it stands up on that scale, I would recommend viewing it over stubbornly giving it a pass. This is cinema.

Based on the terrible reviews online this was a lot better than I was expecting. I found that it was a very accurate representation of mental illness in film especially constantly switching between fantasy and reality. I adored the first film and while this was quite different I also really enjoyed this one. There wasn't nearly as much singing as made out to be online and seriously if you don't like musicals why go watch a musical? The only thing I didn't like was how messy and rushed the ending seemed but this definitely didn't ruin it for me. So if you are worried about the reviews but enjoyed the first movie and understand it's a musical, definitely give it a shot. I will also add that I found this one to be a bit more graphic than the first one with some slightly triggering scenes.

I think that most negative reviewing of this movie stems from the assumed "mis-selling" of what the movie is going to be. I say "assumed" because the movie isn't sold with any premise. I think many (myself included), expected a progression of the jokers story, from the first movie's origin notes, to perhaps his rise to crime lord and Batman's nemesis. Spoiler alert : it doesn't do this. Rather the movie continues to explore the twisted mind and personality of Arthur flex. Joaquin is fantastic as ever at portraying this broken and unstable character and the cinema-photography is beautiful.

In essence this movie does what it does amazingly well. It's shouldn't be put down for breaking moulds and expectations. In fact it should be highly praised for doing so. We need more of this not the derivative formulation bs that is usually piped out of Hollywood.

Rating this as a 10 to counteract all of the ridiculously harsh reviews. For those who have seen the first joker film and were expecting a replica in the sequel have misjudged the story.

Arthur Fleck uses music to escape his reality and makes perfect sense in the context of the film, considering the trauma he has experienced throughout his life and continues to experience.

The music fit seamlessly into the storyline and was really moving. Lady Gaga and Joaquin Phoenix gave phenomenal performances and I strongly advise people to be open minded when watching because it is pleasantly surprising.

Everyone in the theater hated it, but I loved it and saw it for what it was. You just have to watch it through the right kind of eyes. It's not a movie. It's a balladic interpretive artpiece that realistically juxtaposes mental illness against the backdrop of our justice system while disguised as a Broadway musical birthed out of the new and innovative anti-comic style. It can't be given a name. Human society isn't ready for it yet.

Most people sitting in the theater will either be counting the seconds until it's over, or be walking out. It's less about raw entertainment, and more about serving as a mirror to society. It was as if the talent and director were given complete creative freedom, and pushed it to the maximum with little regard for monetary return. It challenges what it means to be mentally ill, as well as questioning our believed differences between justice and punishment -correction and rehabilitation.

Are all criminals guilty of their crimes, or do we as a whole society share some of that guilt for not trying hard enough to enforce our societal integrity?

I absolutely love how the story of the Joker is being shared. Geeesh, Mr. Phoenix brings the Joker to life visually as well as mentally and the musical touch actually takes the tone of the film where it needs to be adding such intimate detail!!!!! Lady Gaga ....great supporting role!!! She was absolutely amazing!!!! The film is such a quiet chaotic work of art that I can truly appreciate being a true fan of the Joker. The writers behind this film really brings this story to life exploring and explaining in great detail the comic book historians identity for sure. From actors to the story line to the musical selections this is definitely a great treat for us Joker fans!!!!

This next installment for the Joker really was excellent! I never looked at my watch during the entire movie. The creativity and attention to detail by the director, special effects, deep story shots were so well planned. I was really blown away by the show tunes that both characters sang at important areas of the film, some lighter some darker. Granted, this is a very violent, dark film not for the sensitive viewer. I study each film that I see and take notes. The amazing colors used too at different points of the film were very inventive and held your attention. It goes more deeply about the Jokers upbringing and hard life he has had than the first film. It also showed abuse as an adult that for most sensitive people could be tough to watch, but I invite you to see other creative points of this....dare I say, Oscar worthy film. I believe Mr. Phoenix could get an Oscar for his exceptional acting as he threw himself totally into his character. Lady Gaga could also may get an award too for her wonderful performance and her gift of her singing. This is the best movie of the year so far in my opinion.

Excellent film!

Everyone hating it, simply doesn't get it..

It's a film about the continued decline of the Arthur/Jokers mental health and a semi-love story.. creating a false reality to hide, split personality disorder and the pain of trauma and living with a devil inside.

This is a perfect avenue for a character such as Joker.

It touches perfectly to the comics and the insanity Joker is/was.. he isn't just portrayed as a "crazy villian".. he is complex, damaged and vulnerable. That's the point.

Folie A Deux is a continuation from part 1, do not expect a "Batman" film.. you won't get it.

The film was marvelous! Joaquin and Gaga did an amazing performance for this film. The cinematography and direction was superb! Although, Gaga's barely in the movie I wanted more of her scenes there are so many scenes in the trailer that its not part of the movie and Gaga is such a eye-catching everytime she appears to the screen she really gets your attention easily - The ending of the movie feels like its hard to digest Todd really destroys the story line I have no problems being musical their singing was amazing, but story line is kinda off but overall I enjoyed watching the film! Kudos to all the cast and crew!

Just came back from the theatre for a second viewing of Folie a Deux and loved it again.

Joker: Folie à Deux is nothing short of mesmerizing. It takes the raw, gritty essence of the first film and layers it with an almost surreal intensity. Joaquin Phoenix, once again, gives a masterclass performance, but this time with the added complexity of a musical twist. The chemistry between Phoenix and Lady Gaga is electric-she brings a whole new dimension to Harley Quinn, not just as Joker's partner, but as a standalone force. The cinematography is stunning, with each shot feeling like a piece of dark, twisted art. And the music! It's haunting, blending seamlessly with the chaos unfolding on screen. This sequel doesn't just repeat the success of the first movie-it expands on it, dives deeper, and makes you think about the madness that exists within all of us. Absolutely brilliant from start to finish!

Firstly, I am an avid moviegoer and with my wife would like to watch most films and give them all a chance.

The original joker film I found very dark and gritty but was an amazing and well acted. Film and Phoenix deserved the Oscar and the film deserved success but it's a film that would probably never watch again.. This film, however was still dark and gritty but with the amazing performance by Gaga Together with another brilliant performance by Phoenix and the musical twist of these two singing to each other was truly inventive and amazing and added to the plot while breaking up some of the gritty parts to make it a much more enjoyable film while telling such an awesome story.

I believe Gaga and Phoenix both deserve Oscars for their performances and would make Phoenix a legend for possibly getting to Oscars for playing the same character. Why the reviews and scores are solo on this is unbelievable because it is way better than what these people are saying..

While I do agree with many that this movie could've been better but I think people are taking things too seriously, the thing is every movie is different and everyone takes it differently so I would advice that you don't base the things you watch off of other people's opinion.

Personally, I am content with the final product. I love the cinematography, every little detail took me deeper into Arthur's mind, I must admit that when I found out it was a musical I thought it might ruin the film but no, in my opinion it really shows how they escape reality with music and their little fantasy world...one thing that did kind of threw me off is the ending..I feel it's not like the traditional characters from comics and other movies but in a nutshell it's a good film.

I wrote a really long review and it isn't appearing now. I rated it 10/10 and imdb changed it to 3/10 which is appalling.

A great film. Internal drama, not a shoot 'em up.

Brilliant performances from Joaquin Phoenix and Lady Gaga.

Showed the impact of trauma, the gift that keeps on giving.

Touches on celebrity culture and inauthenticity, feeling lost and without foundation and clinging to someone in/famous.

Kindnesses, cruelties, coping mechanisms, dissociation, fragmentation with jumping to different times in his life, imagined scenes and musical interludes. Loved these.

Please know I rated this a 10 and if it's downgraded ill know not yo trust imdb scores ever again.

The movie focuses on the relationship between Joker and Harley Quinn, so many people forget who Harley is and her personality. Despite this, the movie is still enjoyable and introduces a larger concept. In the Batman cartoon, Lee Quinzel is always singing, so I don't understand why people are surprised by this in the movie. What did they expect? I appreciate that they didn't change her personality. Perhaps many of us can't accept a deeper view of the characters and stories in the Batman universe, but I believe that if they continue to make movies and series about the same characters in this way, Batman and every superhero will become stale. I like how they are starting to care about other characters; this will revitalize the story.

Being already so invested in the Joker's character from the original Joker, I wasn't expecting the movie to be what it was. Although knowing the Joker's character Arthur Fleck is mentally ill it was definitely complementary that they portrayed a lot of the feelings & scenes through songs. Certainly not a paradox, Joker was psychotic and delusional (schizophrenic?) And ironically loved how music was used as he seemed most happy when he was singing. As we all know music therapy is great for mental health.

Would certainly say I would have liked a bit of action in there and certainly the possibility of a further movie.
