One criticism is that the person they chose to play the Young Harvey Dent was so bad that it nearly ruined many of the scenes. I want to know who that person's relatives are because they didn't get there by ability alone.

Joker makes his deput in one holocaust of crime against the idea of being a hero than a villain that he is! It's inappropriate way to say "real" or "true" for the movie. Filmmaking with such scenario is a new idea standards! Cartoon scheens in the start creates a comic experience than we ever seen before. Its a coming of a new age script for movies with new boundaries! Having read DC comic books and graphic novels such as batman and Robin, Joker Endgame,I have never seen the part of Joker himself. This is the movie to see Joker in one of his own psychological,comedy and Crime movies of 1950's now at the cinemas! At last the second movie is a musical romance! Harley queen (Lady gaga) plays her role on this undergoing thrilling movie!

I watched the original Joker five times when it came out over the span of a month or two. Obviously I couldn't get enough. I don't put a lot of expectations into movies these days. I try to just go in hoping to get a few goosebumps here or there if at all. Joker 2 did do that. It did it toward the end two times. That was unexpected. Joker 2 didn't deliver a carbon copy movie of the first though some of the songs and soundtrack seemed to be the same. It is a movie for people that get something from knowing a director went for it. By that I mean not trying to appease the masses that came in droves to watch the first one. It challenges those that come in thinking they will see Joker be Joker and be triumphant as that, but the movie is about Arthur Fleck. A nobody that one day finds himself a cult hero for the unhappy masses of Gotham. That's no spoiler. That's what happened in the first one. It was poetic. Becoming this thing was almost accidental and we saw that magic grow inside Arthur. We all rooted for him to finally become something even if it meant killing people and destroying his world. We were in that same fantasy state throughout. It was perfect. Then reality hits. That's what Joker 2 I think is about. As that song that is played in the first and second go, "That's Life" Joker 2 takes us on a voyage of what happens to those expectations. Almost meta because we have our own expectations going in wanting Joker once again to succeed in his diabolical plan. Yet without spoiling it we find that life is just that. Nothing special. Joker 2 is an excellent film if you see the magic that it is. It is okay to hate it for now, but it will grow on you if you let yourself also grow. That is the power of a good film. One that has the potential for being watched over the years and getting something else each time. I think this is one of those films.

I love musical, jazz, Lady Gaga, and the first Joker movie. When I saw the trailer I knew it would remind me of Chicago: a nobody who rises to fame because of a murder they commited, and having to go through a trial and "razzle dazzle" attention from the media and society... eventually realizing that everything is only for the sake of "entertainment".

The movie was exactly like what I hoped it to be. I absolutely loved it, the acting was brilliant, the cinematography was as beautiful as the first movie. Watching it on IMAX was definitely a feast for the eyes.

I can see why a lot of people are complaining. Ironically, or should I say interestingly, they are just like the Joker's supporters in the movie. They're only here to see "the Joker", the violent man we all expect him to be. But they all leave the theater once they find out that he's just... Arthur. A sad, depressed, troubled humanbeing living in a real world. For me personally, it's a good thing because it stays true to the first movie. They're not trying to magically turn him into a high-class mafia in one night.

Joker Folie à Deux is hands down the most realistic and controversial take on an antihero franchise. It may get a lot of hate now, but that's just because it is way ahead of its time. It will be a pioneer of a new experimental genre, sparks never-ending discussions, and surely will be a cult film in the upcoming decades. Just like Chicago when it won an Oscar.

In the same way that Arthur, at the end, couldn't play the role others wanted him to play, which made everyone very mad and disappointed in him, this movie wasn't what most people wanted it to be. It was a real movie about a very real and very broken man who, sadly, couldn't possibly get a happy ending. This is the most realistic portrayal and ending for the joker. People want to see him as a crazy martyr, a leader of the oppressed, the spark of the revolution, a clown that just go around doing crazy stuff and not giving a damn anymore, Batman's enemy, but what they got was a hurt man trying to escape his horrible reality with a fantasy, feeding up on all his pseudo glory for a while before realizing he couldn't handle it. That he didn't want to play the role of the clown anymore. Both Gaga's and Phoenix's acting are magical. They really gave everything they had for the roles and they did it masterfully. Everyone is complaining about the musical part but I think it fitted perfectly with Arthur's escapism. Also the direction and photography of this movie are gorgeous. I am not a Batman fan and maybe this is why I didn't mind such a different portrayal of the joker when compared to the comics or Batman's movies. But I really think this is the most human and real joker they could have created. My advice is don't listen to the criticism, go watch it and have your own opinion about it and try not to expect a cartoonish caricature of the joker, because that's not what you are going to get.

It's always admirable when a filmmaker makes a film that defies expectations. And defy expectations Joker 2 does. Influenced by films like Leos Carax's Annette (which was also a major influence behind Megalopolis) or Lars Von Trier's Dancer in the Dark, Joker takes the learning that the musical genre contains in its core the seeds of lunacy and uses it to dive deep into the Joker's psychology.

When Joker 1 came along, it surprised everyone by not even mentioning Batman. Joker 2 pushes the envelope even further, basically staying away from the very Joker character for the entire film. The result is strange, disorienting and many viewers will come out feeling like they were shortchanged. But it's oh so refreshing to see a movie that chooses not to look like a "full-in-the-blanks" form!

Does it all work perfectly? No, and that's why it's rated 8 vs 10. The trial feels long. The joker scenes, albeit imaginary, work okay not great.

But ultimately that's not the issue with Joker 2, which is a good enough movie, maybe one of the best of the year to come out of a studio. The problem, for once, is financial. There is no reason this movie should have cost $200M to make. Anyone reading the script should have known this would not appeal to mass audiences. At a $40 or $50M budget, this would have been an example of how artistic movies targeting adults can be very profitable, and would have encouraged more. Instead, it will go down in history as a massive flop and a financial disaster and will discourage studios from taking similar risks in the future. This is Todd Phillips' responsibility, and one can both appreciate the movie and lament the damage done to filmmaking in general.

I understand that it's not what most people expected to see but how someone can say it's a bad movie..

For sure it's not a typical joker movie with elements of actions and violence that someone would believe it will have but it shows us from a realistic , charming and bold perspective what happened to the mental ill Arthur Fleck after the murders that he committed.

I liked the dark atmosphere of the film, I love Joaquin Phoenix he is a really brilliant actor and the music parts of the film fit in really well. Lady gaga was ok for her part..

I believe that it will be one of the films whose value is recognized years later.

I was captivated by Lady Gaga's portrayal of Lee Harlequin and it was sad at the end. Joaquin's performance of Arthur Fleck Joker was psychologically complex and moving. The multiple layers unravel firstly a sense of helplessness in Arkham Asylum and his social environment with the prison guards. Then hope from his relationship with Lee deepens but understands with love comes lies. The pacing of the film is good it moves easily thru the scenes and never skips a beat. The singing musical aspect didn't take away any of the film for me. I thought it was relevant for the Joker's and Harlequin's relationship also mental state and the scene imagination of his and Harlequin's tv show gives an indication or prediction of the final ending. I don't know what all the negative opinions are about being directed to this film. The performances of Joaquin and Gaga acting / singing, choreography ( esp Joker tap dancing) and cinematography was amazing. Todd Phillips and his production team created a real work of art!

There are way to much innecesary movies made nowadays. Specially franchise spinoffs; prequels, sequels, remakes, multiverses... but not this one.

This is hands down one of the best sequels I have ever seen.

It is pretty concerning that movies like this or Furiosa are being box office failures, but DeadPool vs Lobezno is being sucesful.

If this movie came out 20 years ago when people was able to actually pay attention to a movie it would have been labeled as a masterpiece, but nowadays audience struggles watching something that's not a TikTok video.

A complete re-definition of the first movie that, while mantaining the tone and themes, explores complete different genres and adds new perspectives. All a sequel should be.

A superb production where all departments have been absolutetly brilliant.







-Production design at its peak, with ultra realistic life like scenarios, and imaginary musicals.

-Sound design, music and mixing, all elevating the job of the other departments to the max, with a combination of brilliant original music with other songs, a terrific atmosphere construction and life like dialog recording.

I am rewatching 100%. If you can, go to a Dolby Cinema, the Dolby Vision grading must be a life changing experience.

If you are a fan of great movies then this fits bill. If you are looking for a comic joker redemption and happy ending then this is not it. Reminds me more of a one who flew over the cookoossnest than comic movie. The realism of a sad mentally ill person who craves love and stardom with a psychotic way to achieve that and an enabling sycophant who encourages it. Anyway the progressive detail of a person who wants to die his hole life and comes to the realization of how to achieve it crossed with blind love is amazing. The acting is incredible the cinematic shots are fantastic. The story is sad and people are mad because it's not the story they would have written but we didn't write it. Anyway I loved it.

Ah, I see I have your attention giving this movie 9 stars. I loved it, except I did think toward the end "please, no more singing." But, not because it was a musical (it wasn't, read on). But because I just didn't want to hear anymore singing. But the singing is relevant to this movie, but it's not a musical. And this is why I say that: Music infiltrates every crevice of our lives. We hear music wherever we go and if there is no music playing around us we hear it in our head. When we're in a particular situation we can think of a song related to that or we make up a little song. Some music is prevalent in our lives. So for Joker movie 2 to be a musical makes sense. This is not THE joker (all Capitals), this is a joker. THE joker, the original joker, did not have a name and he was a sociopath. He was disfigured and he got a little angry about that so he took it out on the world. Arthur Fleck is kind of like a parallel universe Joker. He is not the funny and silly joker from the 60s or the excited and psychotic joker from the 70s, etc. This is a different person. This is A joker. And he is not psychotic: he is insane. That's the keyword here: insanity. But even people who are insane still have music in them so it is believable to see someone who is literally insane equating music to different events in their life. That is acceptable, and if you're not accepting that in this movie then you're missing the point. Plus they gave you a big clue in the name of the movie. Those of us who were excited to see this different version of "Not the joker" that I grew up with, took the time to translate what the title is (because I don't know French). And it means madness for two and madness is another name for insanity. These people are insane and if you're trying to fit them into a mould, of the joker that you knew in the past or your own understanding of DC comics, it's not gonna work. Maybe you just need to understand insanity a little bit to be able to get this movie. Life is a musical and we should all be able to see this movie like that through Arthur Fleck's eyes.

Do not expect the first film. Do not expect Suicide Squad. This is not a typical comic book film with crazy Joker that is going to kill even more people and escape in the end with as crazy as him Harley Quinn, this is more than that. This is down to earth story of the Joker. Perceive him as a real person in a real world where laws work. This film is art! Every frame, every detail in it, combination of colours, makeup and costumes, lighting, camera angles and movements, shot sizes are well elaborate. The combination of psychological thriller genre with musical is somewhat risky, experimental. However, result came out as unique and brilliant. I haven't seen any film with this crazy but genial idea, and that's why I loved it! Do not have any expectations before watching, do not prepare yourself to anything but just watch it. Music, performance of the actors are on top. Joaquin and Lady Gaga have a great chemistry in this film. Both complemented each other. Despite that this is a dark story, there are moments you will at least smile on or even laugh at. In general, I would say that this film is a descent continuation and finality of Joker in this specific universe. Film deserves attention, it definitely is over hated for no reason and underrated. I'd say it is a must watch to make your own conclusion and do some thinking instead of giving "coach critics" the power to effect you!

Phoenix once again shows a very sad version of the Joker. Just like the first movie - this movie reflects on how horrible we treat people.

I know that he is a criminal - a murder - but the treatment he receives in the mental facility reminds me of the movies I've watched about the Holocaust.

No one should be treated like that! He is abused 24/7 in ways that no human being should be treated.

I felt so sorry for Arthur. The whole movie was about his hardships - everyone using and abusing him - even Harley. Which is actually very true to life. When you are down - people will make sure they shove your face into the dirt.

This movie is not going to do as well as the first one. There were not many people in the theater when I went to see it. It is not light. It is not the usual defiant Joker that we are used to seeing on the screen.

This movie is a reality check - what Joker would be if he really did exist in our world - an adopted boy who spent most of his childhood being abused and mistreated - growing up into an mentally disturbed adult. He creates the Joker world for himself to escape this horrible world that constantly abuses him.

I was shaken by this movie - it was mind-blowing. The singing just seemed to make Arthur seem even more pathetic.

The Joker and Harley world has always interested me. I dedicated my first humor book to them - "Joker and Harley Poetry" - as a tribute to their twisted romance.

This movie may not appeal to many because of its portrayal of Joker - but it doesn't mean that it wasn't excellent. I gave the first movie a 10 because it was original. Never have I seen Joker in such a realistic manner. This 2nd movie was a continuation of his tragic story.

When you break the audience's expectations, you create a love-it-or-hate-it movie. The movie, while building a character (Lee), deconstructs the main character (Joker). The musical scenes are true dialogues, delirious ones that happen only in Arthur's head, because in the end this movie is about him, and not the Joker, no matter how much Lee tries to bring him in at various moments. Just as the Joker was born, he died, and we're not talking physically. The ending of the movie is surprising, which takes the viewer out of their comfort zone, and if you pay attention in the final seconds, a surprising connection occurs. Some won't like it, others will, and I'm in the second group.

Despite the first movie being a non-musical, I think this one shifts to the song-and-dance world well. Said scenes retain a level of grit that match the tone of the first movie (as opposed to being all-out Broadway glitz, which would have been too much of a tonal shift). Joaquin Phoenix surprised me with his ability to both sing and dance well, and of course Lady Gaga was brilliant. As for Gaga's character of Harleen "Lee" Quinzel, I found her incorporation to not only be an appropriate match for Phoenix but also a unique one. Both Lee and Phoenix's Arthur Fleck disturb and pull at the heart strings while having intense chemistry. There are genuinely funny and heartbreaking moments throughout the movie as well that kept me emotionally engaged.

If you dislike musicals and/or are looking for a movie that resembles Batman: The Animated Series, this movie is probably not for you. But if you want to dive deeper into the depths of the mind of Joker's sympathetic and insane antihero and don't mind song and dance, ignore the bad reviews and give this movie a watch!

Seeing a lot of negative reviews, which I really don't get.

Let's get this straight, no one wants a rehash of the first movie, this is a continued story with the outcome of the previous movie, we now see Arthur Fleck behind bars and going on trial for his murders from the previous movie.

Let's get the musical element out of the way - I thought it was really good and in tune with the theme of the movie Harley Quinn (Lady Gaga) meeting Arthur like a moment in Romeo & Juliet, total chemistry and the perfect duo, it was artistic and fitting of their desired fantasy living in a world that revolves around them.

I thought the cast was brilliant, Joaquin Phoenix once again putting in a top performance, gritty New York as the backdrop was great again and I like the fact the story continued from behind bars, first movie was about self discovery for Arthur, this time it's a case study and a court room drama.

In my opinion the first movie was to showcase Arthur's decent into madness, this movie expands upon that. The musical numbers highlight this in 2 ways. On the tonal shift from the start of some songs being off key voices with little instrumentals to a dark shift in the instrumental giving way to cleaner vocals, larger theatrics, and more accompaniments I believe shows the maddens or that the joker taking over Arthur's psyche. The second way I feel it adds is it continues to play on the unreliable narrator, is he actually singing and dancing or is it all in his head. I think the movie also poses the interesting ethical question, can someone truly be in such a broken state of mind that they are not fully responsible for their actions, and is it a failure of the state for cutting social programs that lead to his decent. Overall I left the theater confused why there were so many negative reviews as I throughly enjoyed it and will likely continue mulling it over until I'm able to watch it again. I think if you go into it expecting to be taking on a journey into the mind of a broken man you will enjoy it a lot more, which is the same mindset I went into the first one with.

A film, like any work of art, isn't meant to meet our expectations, but rather to challenge them. Many anticipated Joker: Folie à Deux to mirror the first film, but its divergence from that narrative is precisely what gives it depth. This sequel doesn't just focus on the Joker as the chaotic villain; it shifts the lens to Arthur, the man behind the mask. Arthur is a person desperately seeking love, recognition, and validation-a man whose life has been shaped by his mother's neglect and emotional mismanagement. His relationship with 'Gaga' represents his first taste of feeling truly seen, and through this connection, the film delves into his struggle to express himself.

The musical numbers, rather than being random, are a window into Arthur's inner world. They serve as his unspoken emotions, giving voice to feelings he can't express in words. In these moments, we witness how Arthur escapes his reality by retreating into the songs in his head, making the film's musical turn a clever narrative device for those open to free-spirited expression.

This isn't a story of good versus evil, but rather a reflection on how society's cruelty can warp a person's psyche. It shows how we can sometimes romanticize the twisted sides of people, while overlooking the more fragile and human aspects. At its core, Folie à Deux reveals the way cruelty can push people into a never-ending loop of psychological pain, when all it might take is a bit of kindness to break that cycle. If you let the film resonate with you, it becomes a poignant commentary on human frailty and society's role in nurturing or destroying it.

Arthur is not THE Joker. He's not intelligent, he's not a criminal genius, he's just a mentally ill loser. Nothing more. He's an insignificant nobody. That was already clearly shown in part 1, but many viewers didn't get it and got it right in the face in this film who Arthur is. A loser. A nobody.

The director knew what people would hate about the film. When they were dancing the audience got quiet and said Lee let's give them what they want and a violent scene was shown. Just as he says at the end that she should please stop singing. He asks because the director knew that the audience didn't want that either. The film plays with the audience's expectations.

Review of Joker: A Clash Between Fantasy and Reality

If you're expecting chaotic action, car chases, and Joker's iconic laughter, you'll leave disappointed. This Joker isn't about sensory overload; it's an allegory, an emotional reflection of sorrow, akin to the hidden pain in Busby Berkeley musicals. While critics missed its dramaturgical brilliance, this film should be seen through a Kafkaesque lens. Trapped in tragedy, Joker is already dead. A tug-of-war unfolds, between the fantasy of an avenging Joker and the brutal reality Phillips and Phoenix force upon us. Joker's fall into humanity is his betrayal, stripping away the fantasy everyone clung to.

I loved the first Joker and felt it was such a pure cinematic experience so naturally I was excited to see this.

Good lord, this was painful. Not only painful but beyond cringe inducing. Reminded me of a bad unfunny SNL skit but worse. Lady Gaga looked like she wished she was anyone but on that set. The whole vibe reeked of embarrassment. I love me a good campy bad movie however this was not even close. It just was so boring and dull.

For example Glitter was a hoot yet Swept Away was just a snore.

The musical numbers kept going on and on and none of them made you feel anything except sheer boredom.

Avoid this movie and go see The Wild Robot instead.

Joker: Folie à Deux is a bold, unexpected sequel that takes significant creative risks, stepping away from the structure of the first film. Instead of merely continuing the revolutionary energy that some might have anticipated, it chooses to deconstruct the very mythos of its predecessor.

The film pivots from the chaotic, gritty narrative of the first Joker and shifts into a surreal, almost self-reflective portrayal of the character's evolution. At its core, Folie à Deux explores the identity of the Joker as something that constantly reinvents itself. The choice to embrace a musical format adds a layer of irony and nostalgia, reflecting an era of innocence and naivety, much like the Joker we might remember from earlier portrayals. The musical elements are not just stylistic flourishes but serve as a commentary on the Joker's transformation-juxtaposing the dark themes with a sense of playful absurdity, reminiscent of older, more innocent times.

However, this innocence does not survive the movie's trajectory. The film carefully dissects the Joker's character, showcasing the tension between the chaotic and the tragic aspects of his identity. Rather than glorifying rebellion, it reveals the futility of the anarchic figure in today's spectacle-driven society. The film seems to say that the "revolutionary" Joker, who became a cultural icon after the success of the first film, has been chewed up and spat out by the same system that made him famous, leaving only a more terrifying, unhinged figure in his place.

Folie à Deux masterfully combines moments of surreal beauty and unsettling psychological depth. It resists being a simple continuation of the first film's success. Instead, it dares to question the very nature of its protagonist and the role of art in our modern world. Some might feel betrayed by the lack of a clear revolutionary narrative, but that is precisely the point. This isn't a film about sparking an uprising-it's about holding up a mirror to the audience and reflecting the chaotic void we often find ourselves in, both as spectators and participants in the modern spectacle of life.

By the end, the film leaves viewers with an unsettling sense of finality, not just for the character but for the innocence of what the Joker once represented. It's a film that challenges expectations, deconstructs its own narrative, and ultimately redefines the character in a way that will provoke deep reflection long after the credits roll.

The new Joker film, which powerfully combines Joaquin Phoenix's raw portrayal with Lady Gaga's nuanced performance, is not only a deep exploration of human vulnerability but also a profound commentary on the brutal consequences of neglect, mental health stigma, and abuse. This film takes audiences on a heart-wrenching journey, revealing the Joker as someone desperately seeking love and acceptance, only to be repeatedly beaten down by society's cruelty.

A key theme is how singing becomes his only refuge, his one means of expressing his inner turmoil. Through music, he connects with Harley Quinn, Lady Gaga's character, and it's the rare form of communication that brings him any sense of relief. Singing is their language, offering brief moments of hope and humanity in a world that continues to crush him. Yet even this relief is fleeting, as his vulnerability is repeatedly exploited, and he is treated like a joke-rewarded only when he performs for others, as though he's less than human.

The film boldly critiques how society treats the mentally ill, showing how those in positions of vulnerability can be manipulated and humiliated. At one point, Joker is degraded to the role of a clown, literally and metaphorically, where he's expected to make others laugh, his pain trivialized and his struggles ignored. The way people exploit his desire for connection and mock his suffering is both shocking and disgusting-yet it's heartbreakingly real. While the film is fictional, it touches on issues that mirror the real world, where vulnerable individuals are often pushed to their limits by cruelty and indifference.

This film is a stark reminder of the consequences of neglecting mental health and treating those in pain as entertainment. It's a devastatingly sad tale of a man who was once kind and caring, but who is ultimately destroyed by the relentless abuse and exploitation he endures. Joker's descent into madness feels inevitable after years of being torn apart by those around him. Society didn't just fail him-it turned him into the monster they feared, only to punish him for it.

This portrayal of Joker is absolutely genius in its layered storytelling, exposing how unchecked cruelty and a lack of compassion can transform even the most vulnerable into something unrecognizable. It's a dark reflection of the world we live in, where people can be pushed too far, and it leaves you questioning how many real-life tragedies could be prevented with just a little more empathy.

Thematically, it was brilliant. Aesthetically, it was gorgeous. It was a dazzling display of lights, that encapsulated the demented imaginative psyche of Arthur Fleck.

Now. --generally in films, I'm usually not a fan of attempts at sympathy to an irredeemable protagonist. Here it works PERFECTLY in this film. Because not only, do we get this , concentrated form of the layered onion that is Arthur fleck unpeeled, we get to learn more about what'd built him up to his present self on trial for murder. He was sexually assaulted, ignored at every turn, demoralized and lied to. He felt so naked... vulnerable and practically violated in the court room scenes.

And the love, or, primary theme of this story.. wow. It worked on every level, and made every Arthur Fleck visual fantasy all the more floaty, for lack of better terms. I found myself grinning at every choreographed dance scene, and upset at every hint at Harley wanting him for attention and chaos, opposed to love.

They had a tug and pull, and it became the primary dilemma for Arthur's character. Really made you FEEL for him. And you shouldn't right?

And this, plea of insanity driving the verdict, felt like such a correct plot device as a means to split Arthur's ethics and identity with 'the joker'. Driving the question, an extension of Arthur fleck? Or a personality made to protect fleck from the abuse.

All this together, made the film excellent. With stellar themes, and things to SAY.

Kept the essence of the original, whilst spinning a new story with an entirely new medium. People'll come to love this movie.

Everyone says how bad this film is due to it being a "musical" it's not even that bad, this film captures Arthur fleck beautifully. As for the musical part it's a few maybe 8-10 songs that are 1 minute even most less then a minute long and people cry over it as if its that bad but it is really not that bad whatsoever not even close matter of fact if you cant deal with 10 minutes of singing then I wouldn't recommend any movies lol. The last hour of the movie is beautiful It's a work of art,I really think that the producers did their thing switching up the genre. Also may I add 10/10 acting from Joaquin Phoenix here.

Joker: Folie À Deux is brilliant precisely because it did not give the people what they wanted. Instead of being a movie about an evil genius, it is a film about the mundanity of life. Serial killers eventually get caught and, despite their best efforts, they never break out of prison. They rant, rave, fantasise, write books and give interviews to the media, thinking that they are so smart and have great plans, but eventually they die in prison, either from old age or killed by a fellow inmate.

This film is also about the morbid obsession society has with people like Richard Ramirez, Charles Manson, et al., personified in this film by the character of Harley Quinn (played by Lady Gaga). Podcasters, authors, lonely pen pals and people who just want to see the world burn view these characters as anti-heroes, but in the end, these killers are not heroes. They are murderers who have accomplished little in life, often have low IQs, leave devastated families in their wake, and rarely show remorse. These killers find it hard to understand the pain they cause to others because they live in a complete fantasy world, as does Joker in this film.

This sequel exposes Joker as being just a delusional and common criminal. The audience keeps expecting great acts of revenge or great acts of romance, but Joker never accomplishes anything great. He is a loser stuck in both a physical and mental prison. Violence and romance only take place in his head but, in real life, he gets beaten, abused and condemned by the system. Viewers expect a cartoonish victory by a cartoonish character, but instead they get a Joker far removed from the comic book pages he was born in.

This film is sad and hard to watch, but, unlike dross trying to be funny with cartoonish violence like Deadpool vs. Wolverine, it is grown up. Although Joker 2 will likely never be loved by the masses, appreciation for it will probably grow among audiences who are into studying characters' mental state rather than sitting there waiting for the next fight scene or for something to go boom.

In its character study, in being perhaps the first downer musical, and in completely failing to give the people what they want, this film is shocking, bold and incredibly frustrating, but it is all the better for it. Instead of the anti-hero we craved, we got a mirror to our society and the dead-end loser we deserve. This is not a comic book. This is real life. Weep for it.

After watching and loving the first Joker film I was keen to see the sequel in spite of some poor reviews.

Although the story line is a continuation the film style is certainly different from the first one in a lot of ways and to be honest I found that refreshing. So many sequels are filmed in repetitive ways and the storylines are predictable ( which I suppose gives some film goers comfort) whereas Folie a Deux takes you out of your comfort zone and gives you a completely new experience Joaquin Phoenix and. Lady Gaga are brilliantly insane together and play their roles of two people united by hiding behind a fantasy facade that takes them away from the reality of their real lives.

Throughout the film both Gaga & Phoenix break into song ( and dance) routines that express their emotions and highlight their craving for the love and attention that they both crave but has sadly eluded them.

I get that some critics were left uncomfortable with the amount of singing in the movie but to me it perfectly emphasised the sad and crazy personalities of the two main characters.

A great film

.

Let's get something straight: this movie is not for everyone. But for me, I absolutely loved it. I think a lot of people hate this movie because it does the complete opposite of what the first film did. It doesn't give people what they want a classic Joker story. What the movie is trying to say is that the world doesn't care about mental health; it cares about spectacle and being entertained. That's part of the reason Arthur became the Joker. This movie shows us that people only care about the Joker, not Arthur Fleck. People just want to see the Joker being a murderous psychopath, terrorizing Gotham, rather than seeing him heal, recover, and go back to who he was.

In my eyes, this movie suggests that the Joker is a personality created by a broken system that doesn't care about mental health. Harley Quinn's character symbolizes us, the audience, and how someone's mental health shouldn't come at the expense of our entertainment. Harley only loves Arthur because he's the Joker, which further drives home that point.

Now, on to the reason why I actually love this movie so much: the cinematography was outstanding; so many of the shots were beautiful and artistic. I loved the musical elements of this film. All the songs were great, and they made me want to get out of my seat and start dancing. I loved the courtroom scenes; they were gripping and engaging.

That said, I can see that there are indeed a lot of flaws in this movie. One issue was the relationship between the Joker and Harley Quinn it felt shallow, at times even stupid, and didn't seem to work well. Another problem was how underutilized Lady Gaga was as Harley Quinn. She could've had a much bigger impact in the movie, but overall, her character was poorly written.

Lastly, I feel like Todd Phillips made this movie a musical because he hated the incel fans of the first film. I actually enjoyed the ending, as it reinforced the idea that the Joker is more of a personality created by a broken system than a person we should look up to. I absolutely adored this movie and think everyone should give it a chance. It might not be everyone's cup of tea but I loved it.

First of all, most people are not prepered to see his favorite super villan in a movie like this. Some people want to see the same super hero/vilan film all the time, the same avenger style as always, only action movies, etc... I bet many people won't watch or will talk badly about this movie ONLY because its a musical.

About the film then. I heard many critisim wannig to kwon what the story is about. The movie is about a realistic Joker. It's about mental heath issues, abuse and violence. Its also a critisim about the judicial and prisional sistem of America and civilization in genaral.

Its a slow story, because the joker is in trial and being a "realistic" movie, he will not blow up jail and run. I think the alternative to make the movie more dinamic and to show more of the over the top and lunatic joker that we kwnow, was to make it a musical. I think it was a great idea and it was perfectly done.

The performances, specially joaquin phoenix, were exceptional. The frames look incredible and the musics are beautiful. I specially love how the "musical parts" start getting more and more frequent and over the top as joker is getting more and more mad. He's of course allucinatining with harley.

In the end I love the movie. My only critisim is about the durating. For a movie with a slow storyline and a different style 2h18h it's too long. Sometimes even good musics became a bit massive because we are already tired.

Said that, Joker 2 Its not better then the first one, but its a very good movie that deserve the recognition of a work well done.

People who rated this movie low clearly didn't understand the movie. They expected a cliche movie.

It shows how society creates a villain and how it kills the same person if they resist to become a villain.

On the other hand when the guy cuts his own face, the story continues in the audience mind that maybe Batman is fighting the fake joker to take the revenge of his own brother, the real joker, who was the victim of everyone around him. His mother, his father, his government that cut his treatment found, his lover, and his fans.

The name of the movie is larger than the frame because this character is huge and won't fit in the frame.

The first Joker was lightning in a bottle, a damn-near perfect standalone experience that left many questions unanswered, something that worked in that film's favour quite wonderfully.

So did Joker 'need' a sequel? No. Yet here we are...

Despite my preference for the tale of Arthur Fleck/Joker (?) to remain shrouded in mystery, I have to admit that Folie à Deux has wormed its way into my mind and my appreciation for it has deepened since leaving the cinema.

I for one applaud the bold creative choices made by Phillips and co. From the Looney Tunes-esque animated intro to the musical numbers peppered throughout that range from understated and solemn to loud and exuberant, it's safe to say that this isn't what people were expecting to see.

The decision to flip these characters on their heads has proved to be understandably controversial. But it's all in line with the ideas and themes the filmmakers set out to explore: the veneration and worship not of the individual but the figure and what they represent, the fascination with high-profile killers granted celebrity status by the media and the masses.

The acting is top-notch as expected, Phoenix's Joker and Gaga's understated Harley in particular shine in every scene. The film looks fantastic with dynamic camerawork and cinematography. Hildur Guðnadóttir also returns with another appropriately sombre and chilling score

Those expecting the Joker & Harley show however will be left wanting.

My initial reaction walking out of Folie à Deux was one of uncertainty and coldness whereas Joker left me feeling emotionally drained in the best way possible. That being said the film has honestly stuck with me, and the more I think about it the more I appreciate the filmmaking on display.

It may not be as tight, poignant or disturbing as the first film and the question surrounding the necessity of a sequel will linger for some time. But I respect it nonetheless and in time, I believe, it will earn the respect it deserves.

I think it is important to see this film for what it is not what you wanted it to be. Todd Phillips is playing with our own (his audiences) madness, and let's face it, we are undoubtedly mad. He is has obviously achieved this successfully and this is made abundantly clear when I read the wording in some of the other reviews here on iMDB. In the first film he introduced us to a character and played with our psyche to the point that we wanted him to kill people, we wanted him to kill the bullies on the train, we felt he was justified to do so. It was all leading up to him appearing on the night show where again, we felt OK and excited about him shooting the host dead. In our own fantasies, by watching a film, should we want people to be murdered just because the world is rigged? We, the audience are essentially the raging crowd at the end of the first film admiring a madman who is helping us get revenge on all thats wrong with the world. The second film, without giving too much away, hints at what the masses, in the real world (if it is indeed real) and the masses in the film that want Arthur set free into the world to start a movement. We, the people watching the film are essentially the people outside the courthouse, though we get to watch it all unfold to our disliking. And that is the point, he wants to spit in our face, that is the true art of this film and in my opinion he has successfully and artfully achieved that feat...

What can I say, the true shared madness is the one between the director and the screenwriter: a sequel so antithetical to the prequel, that it subverts the premises and takes an anarchic approach to delivering a metacinematic reflection as powerful as it is clumsy and superficial, I would have never imagined it.

The musical inserts are unbearable, and the commercial flop seems almost inevitable (the Joker fanbase will feel betrayed - just look at the first IMDb ratings), but it will be remembered as a remarkable case of self-sabotage for a potential blockbuster that risked everything, with no regard for audience expectations or the box office.

Todd Phillips could have taken the easy path paved by the 2019 Joker, culminating in an escalating frenzy of shared violence, satisfying the sadistic viewers who, five years ago, reveled in watching the transformation of an anonymous outcast into DC's most charismatic supervillain.

Instead, this Joker will go down in the history of cinema for diametrically opposite reasons, leaving theaters empty.

The cast is brilliant. There is chemistry throughout, even in the supporting performances.

The production value has been outragely raised, but we see not that much more of Gotham City in the 1980s.

Cinematography, production design and music are all Hollywood top notch. But the editorial lingers too long in cell, corridors and backyards which technically could save the picture 15min in running time.

The first thing I heard in an half-full IMAX auditorium by just a guy with his girlfriend seating in my route "What a let down".

I think two or three dialogues should have been in place without singing due to the script by Silver/Phillips. The Harley/Joker stage show scene would have had more impact.

My conclusion, there are huge opportunities lost because of the sheer anticipation by the mass movie audience.

07/10.

Well look what happens when Todd Phillips doesn't directly rip off a movie and creates something on his own.

I hope this exposes him for the hack that he is and all of you realize just how bad the first movie really was.

Phillips doesn't actually have anything to say and these jokers movies were only created so he could "turn the superhero genre on it's head." He thinks he's capable of much more talent and didn't create these movies for any other reason than to be a contrarian. And that's not how real art or good art is made.

This was obvious when this "anti superhero movie" not only set itself up for a sequel but then made one. And a musical? You know the thinking was, "What's the last thing that anyone would do in a superhero movie?" Phillips sucks.

Horrible? No. Cinematic trainwreck? Far from it! Disappointing? Absolutely.

There was no chance this would live up to the first "Joker," even though, like previously, I went in with unreasonably high expectations, despite the reviews out of Venice being mixed-to-negative. I honestly wanted to ignore them since the first "Joker" wasn't as well-received either, at least by critics. I saw that film a few months back, and it was fantastic! It came across as a movie dedicated to developing the Joker beyond what the Batman movies beforehand showed him off as, making for a tragic and shocking watch. Was a sequel to the first "Joker" necessary? Not really, since there was nowhere to take the story that would feel natural - and it shows.

It's not as bad as people say it is, but it is hard to ignore the flaws and appreciate the positives, and they were a lot for me.

First, even if this film failed, the aspects that could not possibly fail were the performances and all the actors delivered. Despite his character taking a unique direction I'll discuss in a second, Joaquin Phoenix does outstanding work as Arthur Fleck / The Joker. He feels more constrained since he is in custody for his actions in the first film, but Phoenix makes his character believable. Lady Gaga does a great job as Lee Quinzel or Harley Quinn, although she is never called that. Weird.

Before talking about another positive, they marketed this as a musical. It works to an extent, with two phenomenal musical sequences, but it's easy to remove them entirely. They weren't original, as they licensed songs for the characters to cover, which makes me wonder if they spent most of the $200M budget on songs. Also, how did this film cost $200M? We'll get to the directing in a second, but how the film was shot and structured could have easily been made on a $100M budget, not a $200M budget. John Wick: Chapter 4 cost $100M, and it looks fantastic, has mind-blowing action, and feels like a film they spent more money on. It should have happened with "Joker: Folie à Deux." If projections are anything to go by, we are looking at a potential box-office bomb!

Okay, now the directing. Todd Phillips delivered, especially when it came to the music sequences. There are many interesting shots that I would call remarkable, on top of moments that land outside of the sequences. Additionally, Hildur Guðnadóttir's score was excellent, which made the scenes more emotional and extravagant than they have any right to be.

I also appreciated the film focusing on the Trial of the Joker rather than the Joker wreaking havoc. It's not as good as what Joker did in the first, but it was compelling, for the most part. That, however, leans into my first negative. The film's focus on the trial leads to scenes dragging and not engaging. The unnecessary musical numbers feel like they were supposed to keep the movie's pacing from feeling boring. I'm glad I don't have to title this review "Joker: Folie à Deuzzzzzz."

I might as well talk about the rest of the negatives. There were many unnecessary scenes outside the music, or they felt inessential and threatened to drag down the movie's momentum.

I didn't entirely appreciate Joker or Lee Quinzel's portrayals in this film. Given the circumstances, Joker at least feels consistent, but I must say that Quinzel wasn't that captivating. For the most part, she was extraordinary, and I felt her connection with the Joker. Unfortunately, once the ending happened, I ceased to care about her character, which is a huge problem since they advertised this as her movie alongside the Joker.

Also, can we talk about that ending? It's teetering on bad and brings the entire experience down. I liked this movie up until that ending, but it was such a letdown that I more or less respect the film more than I like it.

In closing, "Joker: Folie à Deux" is almost guaranteed to disappoint. It's in the running for the most disappointing film of the year alongside "Kingdom of the Planet of the Apes" and "I Saw the TV Glow." It's an incredibly ambitious movie, but those ambitions make it sound incredibly out-of-tune.

Technically, impressive. The directing, the score, and all the performances stand above the good, if misguided, screenplay, making it an easy 8/10.

For the enjoyment score, it depends. I know you better than me, so I'll say if you are expecting a film that is as fast-paced and thought-provoking as the first, you are in for a discouraging and possibly depressing experience. If you are expecting a film that may not impress general audiences but can feed into that film lover in you, go see "The Substance" or rewatch the first one again. For me, my respect for the film helps to make the enjoyment score a 6/10. It's hard to determine who will like or love this movie, and I'm not even sure it's worth seeing in theaters. I didn't regret my time with it, but it may get worse for me with time, and you're better off waiting to rent or stream it on Max.

You know from the beginning that it won't come close to the first movie at all. However, the beginning of the film with the comic is clever. You want to see how the film will develop. The strong scenes that will make you watch a movie again are missing, while the songs for such a movie are too many and many times they don't even seem to relate to the situations taking place.

The character of Harley Quinn has nothing to do with what we know from the comics. The end of the film is completely disappointing. Poor script, bad idea for a musical.

Joaquin Phoenix is amazing once again.

Lady Gaga would make a nice Harley Quinn if she had the chance to develop the comic character more.
